sentence: The paper proposes a way to pre-train quantized representations for speech.
label: none

sentence: The approach proposed is a two-stage process: 1. train a quantized version of wav2vec [my understanding is that wav2vec is the same thing as CPC for Audio except for using a binary cross-entropy loss instead of InfoNCE softmax-cross entropy loss].
label: none

sentence: the authors propose to use gumbel softmax / VQ codebook for the vector quantization.
label: none

sentence: 2. once you have a discrete representation, you could train BERT (as if it were a seq of language tokens).
label: none

sentence: this makes a lot of sense especially given that CPC / wav2vec recovers phonemes and quantizing the phonemes will recover a language-like version of the raw audio. And running BERT across those tokens will allow you to capture the dependencies at the phoneme level.
label: none

sentence: After pre-training, the authors use the learned representations for speech recognition.
label: none

sentence: They compare this to using log-mel filterbanks.
label: none

sentence: The results (WER / LER) is lower for the proposed pipeline compared to using dense wav2vec representation for n-gram and character LM.
label: none

sentence: It also makes sense that BERT helps for the k-means (vq) setting since the number of codes is large.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The authors also cleverly adopt/adapt span-BERT which is more suited to this setting.
label: none

sentence: I think this paper presents a useful contribution as far as improving speech / phoneme recognition using self-supervised learning goes, and also has useful engineering aspects in terms of combining CPC and BERT. I would like to see this paper accepted.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: This paper explores maximally expressive linear layers for jointly exchangeable data and in doing so presents a surprisingly expressive model.
label: none

sentence: I have given it a strong accept because the paper takes a very well-studied area (convolutions on graphs) and manages to find a far more expressive model (in terms of numbers of parameters) than what was previously known by carefully exploring the implications of the equivariance assumptions implied by graph data.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The result is particularly interesting because the same question was asked about exchangeable matrices (instead of *jointly* exchangeable matrices) by Hartford et al. [2018] which lead to a model with 4 bases instead of the 15 bases in this model, so the additional assumption of joint exchangeability (i.e. that any permutations applied to rows of a matrix must also be applied to columns - or equivalently, the indices of the rows and columns of a matrix refer to the same items / nodes) gives far more flexibility but without losing anything with respect to the Hartford et al result (because it can be recovered using a bipartite graph construction - described below).
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: So we have a case where an additional assumption is both useful (in that it allows for the definition of a more flexible model) and benign (because it doesn't prevent the layer from being used on the data explored in Hartford et al.).
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: I only have a couple of concerns:
label: none

sentence: 1 - I would have liked to see more discussion about why the two results differ to give readers intuition about where the extra flexibility comes from.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The additional parameters of this paper come from having parameters associated with the diagonal (intuitively: self edges get treated differently to other edges) and having parameters for the transpose of the matrix (intuitively: incoming edges are different to outgoing edges).
label: none

sentence: Neither of these assumptions apply in the exchangeable setting (where the matrix may not be square so the diagonal and transpose can't be used).
label: arg_other

sentence: Because these differences aren't explained, the synthetic tasks in the experimental section make this approach look artificially good in comparison to Hartford et al.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: The tasks are explicitly designed to exploit these additional parameters - so framing the synthetic experiments as, "here are some simple functions for which we would need the additional parameters that we define" makes sense; but arguing that Hartford et al. "fail approximating rather simple functions" (page 7) is misleading because the functions are precisely the functions on which you would expect Hartford et al. to fail (because it's designed for a different setting).
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: 2 - Those more familiar of the graph convolution literature will be more familiar with GCN [kipf et al. 2016] / GraphSAGE [Hamilton et al. 2017] / Monti et al [2017] / etc.. Most of these approaches are more restricted version of this work / Hartford et al. so we wouldn't expect them to perform any differently from the Hartford et al.  baseline on the synthetic dataset, but including them will strengthen the author's argument in favour of the work.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: I would have also liked to see a comparison to these methods in the the classification results.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: 3 - Appendix A - the 6 parameters for the symmetric case with zero diagonal reduces to the same 4 parameters from Hartford et al. if we constrained the diagonal to be zero in the output as well as the input.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: This is the case when you map an exchangeable matrix into a jointly exchangeable matrix by representing it as a bipartite graph [0, X; X^T, 0].
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: So the two results coincide for the exchangeable case. Might be worth pointing this out.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: This paper proposed "F pooling" for Frequency Pooling, which is a pooling operation satisfying shift equivalence and anti-aliasing properties.
label: none

sentence: The method is very simple: first, transform the input 1D/2D signal into the spectrum domain based on discrete Fourier transform (DFT), then cut the high-frequencies, then transform back to the time domain using the inverse DFT.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The method can be implemented using FFT and auto differentiation frameworks.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The method is tested on Resnet/Desnet on CIFAR-100 and subsets of ImageNet, showing better performance than the original models.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The reviewer votes for rejection as the method has limited novelty.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Spectrum pooling has been used in the community of computer vision and machine learning.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Taking a random example (there are others by simple searching), in the ECCV paper "DFT-based Transformation Invariant Pooling Layer for Visual Classification, Ryu et al., 2018" The DFT magnitude pooling is almost the same as the authors' propositions, where the "Fourier coefficients are cropped by cutting off high-frequency components".
label: asp_originality

sentence: The reviewer encourages the authors to make further new developments and have a more comprehensive literature review. But in the current form, the paper has less value to be published in ICLR.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: This paper proposed a framework to incorporate GAN into MAP inference process for general image restoration.
label: none

sentence: First, the motivation of the proposed framework is not convincing for me.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: That is, authors assumed that they have a degradation function F and all the inference process is just based on this known function.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: However, in real world scenarios, it is actually challenging to obtain exact degradation information.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Thus we may only apply the proposed model on a few tasks with exactly known F.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Second, due to the norm based constraints, authors actually need to optimize a highly nonconvex optimization problem.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Moreover, due to the trace based loss function, the computational cost will also be very high.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Please notice that standard MAP based methods only need to solve a simple convex optimization model (e.g., TV) and these methods can also be applied for different restoration tasks.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Actually, we only need to specify particular fidelity terms for different tasks.
label: none

sentence: Moreover, very recent works have also successfully incorporate both generative and discriminative network architectures (e.g., [1,2]) into the optimization process.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Therefore, I cannot find any advantage in the proposed method, compared with these existing MAP based image restoration approaches.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Finally, the experimental part is also too weak to evaluate the proposed method.
label: asp_substance

sentence: As I have mentioned above, actually a lot of methods have been developed to address general image restoration tasks.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Some works actually also incorporate generative and/or discriminative networks into MAP inference process for these tasks.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Thus I believe authors must compare their method with these state-of-the-art approaches.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Moreover, authors should conduct experiments on state-of-the-art benchmarks, including natural images.
label: asp_substance

sentence: This is because the digitals images in MNIST do not have rich texture and detail structures, thus are not very challenging for standard image restoration methods.
label: asp_substance

sentence: [1]. Kai Zhang, Wangmeng Zuo, Shuhang Gu, Lei Zhang: Learning Deep CNN Denoiser Prior for Image Restoration. CVPR 2017: 2808-2817
label: none

sentence: [2]. Jiawei Zhang, Jin-shan Pan, Wei-Sheng Lai, Rynson W. H. Lau, Ming-Hsuan Yang: Learning Fully Convolutional Networks for Iterative Non-blind Deconvolution. CVPR 2017: 6969-6977
label: none

sentence: Summary:
label: none

sentence: This paper introduces Amortized Proximal Optimization (APO) that optimizes a proximal objective at each optimization step.
label: none

sentence: The optimization hyperparameters are optimized to best minimize the proximal objective.
label: none

sentence: The objective is represented using a regularization style parameter lambda and a distance metric D that, depending on its definition, reduces the optimization procedure to Gauss-Newton, General Gauss Newton or Natural Gradient Descent.
label: none

sentence: There are two key convergence results which are dependent on the meta-objective being optimized directly which, while not practical, gives some insight into the inner workings of the algorithm.
label: none

sentence: The first result indicates strong convergence when using the Euclidean distance as the distance measure D.
label: none

sentence: The second result shows strong convergence when D is set as the Bregman divergence.
label: none

sentence: The algorithm optimizes the base optimizer on a number of domains and shows state-of-the-art results over a grid search of the hyperparameters on the same optimizer.
label: none

sentence: Clarity and Quality: The paper is well written.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Originality: It appears to be a novel application of meta-learning.
label: asp_originality

sentence: I wonder why the authors didn’t compare or mention optimizers such as ADAM and ADAGRAD which adapt their parameters on-the-fly as well.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Also how does this compare to adaptive hyperparameter training techniques such as population based training?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Significance:
label: none

sentence: Overall it appears to be a novel and interesting contribution.
label: asp_originality

sentence: I am concerned though why the authors didn’t compare to adaptive optimizers such as ADAM and ADAGRAD and how the performance compares with population based training techniques.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Also, your convergence results appear to rely on strong convexity of the loss.
label: none

sentence: How is this a reasonable assumption?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: These are my major concerns.
label: none

sentence: Question: In your experiments, you set the learning rate to be really low. What happens if you set it to be arbitrarily high? Can you algorithm recover good learning rates?
label: asp_substance

sentence: This paper proposed Compound Density Networks (CDNs), a neural network architecture that parametrises conditional distributions as infinite mixtures, thus generalising the traditional finite mixture density networks (MDNs).
label: none

sentence: The authors realise CDNs by treating the weights of each neural network layer probabilistically, and letting them be matrix variate Gaussians (MVGs) with their parameters given as a function of the layer input via a hypernetwork.
label: none

sentence: CDNs can then be straightforwardly optimised with SGD for a particular task by using the reparametrization trick.
label: none

sentence: The authors further argue that in case that overfitting is present at CDNs, then an extra KL-divergence term can be employed such that the input dependent MVG distribution is close to a simple prior that is input agnostic.
label: none

sentence: They then proceed to evaluate the predictive uncertainty that CDNs offer on three tasks: a toy regression problem, out-of-distribution example detection on MNIST/notMNIST and adversarial example detection on MNIST and CIFAR 10.
label: none

sentence: The objective of this work is to provide a method for better uncertainty estimates from deep learning models.
label: none

sentence: This is an important research area and relevant for ICLR.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: The paper is generally well written with a clear presentation of the proposed model.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The generalisation from the finite MDN to the continuous CDN seems straightforward, the model is relatively easy to implement and it is evaluated extensively against several modern baselines.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Nevertheless, I believe that it still has to address some points in order to be better suited for publication:
label: arg_other

sentence: - It seems that the model is not very scalable; while the authors do provide a way of reducing the necessary parameters that the hypernetwork has to predict, minibatching can still be an issue as it is implied that you draw a separate random weight matrix for each datapoint due to the input specific distribution (as shown at Algorithm 1).
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Is this how you implemented minibatching in practice? How easily is this applied to convolutional architectures?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - How many samples did you use from p(theta|x) during training?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: It seems that with a single sample the method becomes an instance of VIB [1], only considering the weights of the network as latent variables rather than the hidden units.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - The experiments were entirely focused on uncertainty quality but we are always interested in both performance on the task at hand as as well as good uncertainty estimates. What was the performance based on e.g. classification accuracy on each of these tasks compared to the baselines? I believe that including these results will strengthen the paper and provide a more complete picture.
label: asp_substance

sentence: - Have you checked / visualised what type of weight distributions do CDNs capture? It would be interesting to see if e.g. the marginal (across the dataset) weight distribution at each layer has any multimodality as that could hint that the network learns to properly specialise to individual data points.
label: asp_substance

sentence: - The authors mention that in order to avoid overfitting they add an extra (weighted) KL-divergence term to the log-likelihood of the dataset, that encourages the weight distributions for specific points to be close to simple priors.
label: none

sentence: How influential is that extra term to the uncertainty quality that you obtain in the end?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: How does this term affect the learned distributions in case of CDNs?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Furthermore, the way that CDNs are constructed seems to be more appropriate at capturing input specific uncertainty (i.e. aleatoric) rather than global uncertainty about the data (i.e. epistemic).
label: none

sentence: I believe that for the specific uncertainty evaluation tasks this paper considers the latter is more appropriate.
label: none

sentence: More discussion on both of these aspects can help in improving this paper.
label: asp_substance

sentence: As a final point; the hyper parameters that were tuned for the MNF, noisy K-FAC and KFLA baselines are not on common ground.
label: asp_substance

sentence: For noisy K-FAC and MNF the lambda (which should be fixed to 1 for a correct Bayesian model) was tuned and in general lower than 1 lambdas lead to models that are overconfident and hence underperform on uncertainty tasks.
label: asp_substance

sentence: For KFLA a hyper parameter “tau” was tuned; this hyperparameter instead corresponds to the precision of the Gaussian prior on the parameters.
label: none

sentence: In this case, KFLA always optimises a “correct” Bayesian model for every value of the hyperparameter whereas MNF and noisy K-FAC do not.
label: none

sentence: Thus I believe that it would be better if you consider the same hyper parameter on all of these methods, e.g. the precision of the Gaussian prior.
label: asp_substance

sentence: [1] Deep Variational Information Bottleneck
label: none

sentence: [Summary]
label: none

sentence: This paper presents a multi-task learning approach for VQA that represent a solver for each task as a neural module that calls existing modules in a program manner.
label: none

sentence: The authors manually design the task hierarchy and propose a progressive module network to recursive calls the lower modules and gather the information by soft-attention.
label: none

sentence: The final prediction uses all the states and question to infer the final answers.
label: none

sentence: The authors verify the effectiveness of the proposed method on the performance of different tasks and modules.
label: none

sentence: Experiment on VQA shows the proposed model benefits from utilizing different modules.
label: none

sentence: The authors also qualitatively show the model's reasoning process and human study on judging answering quality.
label: none

sentence: [Strength]
label: none

sentence: 1. The proposed method is novel and explores to use the existing modules as a black box for visual question answering.
label: asp_originality

sentence: This is different from most existing work.
label: asp_originality

sentence: 2: By examing different modules, the proposed method is more interpretable compare to canonical methods.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 3: The experiment results are good, especially for the counting problem.
label: asp_substance

sentence: [Weakness]
label: none

sentence: 1. The title of the paper is "visual reasoning by progressive module networks." The title may be a little overstated since the major task is focused on visual question answering (VQA).
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 2. Annotation is not clear in this paper.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: For example, on page 3, Query transmitter and receiver, "the output o_k = M_k(q_k) received from M_k is modified using receiver function as v_k = R_{k->n}(s^t, o_k).
label: none

sentence: " There are multiple new variables in this paragraph, without specifying the dimension and meaning for each attribute, it's really hard to understand.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: On page 4, State update function, what is the meaning of variable "Epsilon" in the equation?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: From the supplementary, it seems Epsilon means the environment?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 3. On the object counting task, the query transmitter needs to produce a query for a relationship module.
label: none

sentence: The authors mentioned that this is softly calculated by softmax on the importance score.
label: none

sentence: Since q_rel require one hot vector as input, how to sample the q_rel given the importance score and how backprob the gradient in this case?
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 4. The cider score of image captioning is 109 compared to the baseline 108.
label: none

sentence: The explanation is the COCO dataset has a fixed set of 80 object categories and does not benefit from training the diverse data.
label: none

sentence: Since the input visual feature is the same, the only difference is the proposed model has additional label embedding as input.
label: none

sentence: My assumption is the visual feature already contains the label information for image captioning.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 5. On relational detection task, is there a way to compare with the STOA method on some specific data split? This will leads to much more convincing results.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 6. Similar as above question, on the object counting task, is there a way to compare with previous counting methods?
label: asp_substance

sentence: 7. In Table 4, the accuracy of number on Zhang et.al is 49.39, which is higher than other methods, while on test-dev, the accuracy is 51.62, which is lower than others.
label: none

sentence: Is the number right?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: This paper studies non-additive utility aggregation for sets.
label: none

sentence: The problem is very interesting.
label: none

sentence: Choquet Integral is used to deal with set input.
label: none

sentence: The authors propose two architectures.
label: none

sentence: The two architectures, though not novel enough, are towards representing “non-additive utility”.
label: none

sentence: However, the experimental comparison is not fair, the description of the model (e.g. how Choquet is integrated into the model and help to learn “intermediate meaningful results”) is not clear, some claims are not true.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: First, the authors claim that they are the first to combine Choquet integral with deep learning.
label: none

sentence: However, there are a few, though not many, works in the literature trying to combine Choquet integral with deep learning.
label: asp_originality

sentence: For example, “Fuzzy Choquet Integration of Deep Convolutional Neural Networks for Remote Sensing” by Derek T. Anderson et al.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Second, the authors claim they are using/motivated by Choquet integral, but do not have any (appendix) sections to explain how this mathematical tool is really integrated into their models.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: How do you guarantee that the representation learned by the neural network still obeys the property of Choquet integral? What is your loss or your algorithm?
label: asp_replicability

sentence: These need to be further clarified.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: Third, the comparison to baseline and “DeepSet” is not fair.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: According to the illustration, it seems that you first obtain “features/representations”.
label: none

sentence: Then the representations are fed to the four architectures you listed in figure one.
label: none

sentence: RNN-based approaches are with better “complexity” comparing to your sum baseline and “Deepset” approach.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: So, I have some doubts about the experimental results.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Paper summary - This paper extends the differentiable plasticity framework of Miconi et al. (2018) by dynamically modulating the plasticity learning rate.
label: none

sentence: This is accomplished via an output unit of the network which defines the plasticity learning rate for the next timestep.
label: none

sentence: A variation on this dynamic learning rate related to eligibility traces is also proposed.
label: none

sentence: Both dynamic modulation variations strikingly outperform non-plastic and plastic non-modulated recurrent networks on a cue-reward association task with high-dimensional cues.
label: none

sentence: The methods marginally outperform plastic non-modulated recurrent networks on a 9x9 water maze task.
label: none

sentence: Finally, the authors show that adding dynamic plasticity to a small LSTM without dropout improves performance on Penn Treebank.
label: none

sentence: The paper motivates dynamic plasticity by analogy to the hypothesized role of dopamine in reward-driven learning in humans and animals.
label: none

sentence: Clarity -  The paper is very clear and well written.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The introduction provides useful insights, motivates the work convincingly, and provides interesting connections to past work.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Originality - I don't know of any other work that models the role of dopamine in quite this way, or that applies dynamic plasticity modulation in settings like these.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Quality - The experiments are well chosen and seem technically sound.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Significance - The results show that meta-learning by gradient descent to modulate the plasticity learning rate is a promising direction -- a significant contribution in my view.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Other Comments - The citation to Zaremba et al. in Table 1 made it seem like the perplexity result on that line of the table was directly from Zaremba et al's paper. I'd recommend removing the citation from that line to avoid confusion.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: One thing I would have loved to see from this paper is a comparison of modulated-plasticity LSTMs with the sota from Melis et al., 2017.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: I gather that Experiment 3 presents small LSTMs without recurrent dropout instead because combining plasticity and dropout proved challenging (or at least the authors haven't tried it yet).
label: none

sentence: I think the paper is solid as-is; positive results in this comparison would take it to the next level.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Questions:
label: none

sentence: Why were zero-sequences necessary in Experiment 1?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: This aspect of the task seems somewhat contrived, and it makes me wonder whether the striking failure of the non-modulated RNNs depends on this detail.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Perhaps the authors could clarify on what a confounding "time-locked scheduling strategy" would look like in this task?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Why does Experiment 1 present pairs of stimuli, rather than high-dimensional individual stimuli?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Why is non-plastic rnn left out of Figure 2b?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Typos
label: none

sentence: "However, in Nature," -- no caps
label: asp_clarity

sentence: in appendix: "(see Figure A.4)" -- the figure is labeled "Figure 3"
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The paper presents an approach to extract a character from a video and then maneuver that character in the plane, optionally with other backgrounds.
label: none

sentence: The character is then redrawn into the background with a neural net, and all of this is done in real time.
label: none

sentence: All in all, this paper was well structured and extensively detailed wrt how it engineered this solution (and why).
label: asp_clarity

sentence: If I had a complaint, it would be that I did not learn anything scientifically from the paper.
label: asp_substance

sentence: There isn't a tested hypothesis, but rather it's a feat of engineering to get this to work.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Those are important as well for the field, and I suspect that this direction could be pushed a lot more.
label: none

sentence: For example, it's not close to getting realistic spatial movement relative to the plane nor is the control that impressive wrt limbs.
label: asp_substance

sentence: However, as a next-contribution, this work deserves to be seen more widely.
label: none

sentence: Hence, I rate it as a weak accept.
label: arg_other

sentence: * Summary
label: none

sentence: This paper addresses machine reading tasks involving tracking the states of entities over text.
label: none

sentence: To this end, it proposes constructing a knowledge graph using recurrent updates over the sentences of the text, and using the graph representation to condition a reading comprehension module.
label: none

sentence: The paper reports positive evaluations on three different tasks.
label: none

sentence: * Review
label: none

sentence: This is an interesting paper.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: The key technical component in the proposed approach is the idea that keeping track of entity states requires (soft) coreference between newly read entities and locations and the ones existing in the knowledge graph constructed so far.
label: none

sentence: The proposed method seems plausible, but some details are impressionistic and it is not clear why and whether the modeling choices do what the paper says.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: This is especially the case in a few places involving coreference:
label: none

sentence: 1. The paper says at the top of page 6 that the result of Eq 1 is a disambiguated intermediate node representation.
label: none

sentence: 2. The self attention in Eq 2 performs coreference disamguation which prevents different instances of the same location from being predicted for multiple entities.
label: none

sentence: While these may indeed be working as advertised, it would be good to see some evaluation that verifies that after learning, what is actually happening is coreference.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Why does the graph update require coreference pooling again?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Don't the updates in Eq 1 and 2 take care of this? The ablation does not test this, right?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Another modeling choice that is not clear is regarding how the model processes the text -- reading prefixes of the paragraph, rather than one sentence at a time. What happens if the model is changed to be read one sentence at a time?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: That the model implicitly learns constraints from data is interesting!
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Bottomline: The paper presents interesting ideas and good results, but would be better if the modeling choices were better explored/motivated.
label: none

sentence: This paper describes the method for performing self-training where the unlabeled datapoints are iteratively added to the training set only if their predictions by the classifier are confident enough.
label: none

sentence: The contributions of this paper are to add datapoints based on the prediction of the confidence level by a separate selection network and a number of heuristics applied for better selection.
label: none

sentence: On the experimental side, the contribution is to test the scenario where datapoints from irrelevant classes are included in the unlabeled dataset.
label: none

sentence: The paper is written in a way that makes following it a bit difficult, for example, the experimental setups.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Also, the writing can be improved by making the writing more concise and formal (examples of informal: "spoil the network", "model is spoiled", "problem of increased classes", "many recent researches have been conducted", "lots of things to consider for training", "supervised learning was trained" etc.).
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The contributions of the method could also be underlined more clearly in the abstract and introduction.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The description of consistency regularisation methods in section 2.2 is not very clear and I would like to get better understanding of temporal ensembling and SNTG methods here as they play an important role in the experiments.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The idea of selective sampling for self-training is promising and the investigated questions are interesting.
label: asp_originality

sentence: As far as I understand, the main contribution of this paper is the use of separate "selection network" to estimate the confidence of predictions by "classification network".
label: asp_originality

sentence: However, as the "selection network" uses exactly the same input as "classification network", it is hard to imagine how it can learn additional information.
label: asp_originality

sentence: For example, imagine the case of binary classification.
label: none

sentence: If the selection network predicts 0 in come cases, it can be used to improve the result of "classification network" by flipping the corresponding label.
label: none

sentence: How can you interpret such a thought experiment?
label: asp_substance

sentence: One could understand the use of "selection network" as a way to automatically select a threshold of what to consider confident, however, in this case, the prediction of "selection network" should be thresholded at 0.5 (correct prediction or not), but the experiments use complex thresholds.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Could you elaborate more on why the selection network is needed? How would it compare to a simple strategy of only including the datapoints whose top-1 prediction of "classification network" is greater than some threshold?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Finally, could you show a plot of top-1 prediction of "classification network" vs score of "selection network" and elaborate on that?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Then, in sections 3.2 and 3.3 the authors introduce a few additional tricks for self-training: exclude datapoints whose predictions are changing and balance the classes.
label: none

sentence: Intuitively, these criteria are well motivated, but unfortunately, the combination of all the intuitions (including "selection network" with threshold) is not very principled.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Ablation study shows that the use of the "selection network" strategy does not improve the results without these heuristics.
label: asp_substance

sentence: It would be interesting to see how these heuristics would do without "selection network", for example, either by doing simple self-training with thresholding on the score of the classifier or by applying only these heuristics in combination with TempEns+SNTG.
label: asp_substance

sentence: In the current form of evaluation, it is hard to say if there is any benefit of using the "selection network" that is the main novelty of the paper.
label: asp_originality

sentence: It is very valuable that the experimental results include many recently proposed methods.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Besides, the settings are described in details that could help for the reproducibility of the results.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: However, I have a few concerns about the results.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: First of all, the proposed SST algorithm alone only performs better than baselines in 1 case, equal to them in 1 case and worse in 1 (table 3).
label: asp_originality

sentence: Besides, as the base classifier is different for various baselines, it is hard to compare the methods.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Then, the important hyperparameter of the method---threshold---seems to be hard to select (both in sections 4.1 and 4.2).
label: asp_clarity

sentence: How did you chose the current values? How sensitive is it? Why various datasets need different settings? How the threshold value can be set in practice?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Another important parameters is the number of iterations of the algorithm.
label: asp_substance

sentence: How was it chosen?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Concerning the experiments of section 4.2, how would the baseline methods of section 4.1 do in this case? Why did you select to study animal vs non-animals sets of classes?
label: asp_substance

sentence: What would happen if you use random class splits or split animal classes (like in a more realistic scenario)?
label: asp_substance

sentence: To conclude, while I find the studied problem quite interesting and intuitions behind the method very reasonable, the current methodology is not very principled and the experiment evaluation did not convince me that such an elaborate strategy is needed.
label: none

sentence: Some questions and comments:
label: none

sentence: - The setting of including unrelated classes in the unlabeled data resembles transfer learning setting. Could you explain why the ideas from transfer learning are not applicable in your case?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - In the training procedure of "selection network" of Sections 3.1, do you use the same datapoints to train a "classification network" and "selection network"? If it is the case, how do you insure that the "classification network" does not learn to fit the data perfectly and thus all labels s_i are 1?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - In the last sentences of the first paragraph on p.2 you make a contrast between using softmax and sigmoid functions, however, normally the difference between them is their use in binary or multiclass classification. Is there anything special that you want to show in you case?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - What do you mean in section 3.3 by "if one class dominates the dataset, the model tends to overfit"?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - I think parameters of training the networks from the beginning of section 4 could be moved to the supplementary materials.
label: arg_other

sentence: - Figure 3: wouldn't the plot of accuracy vs amount of data be more suitable here?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: - Synthetic experiments of supplementary materials: the gains of the methods seem to be small. What are the numerical results? What would happen if you allow to select starting point at random (a more realistic case)?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - Can you explain the sentence "To prevent data being added suddenly, no data was added until 5 iterations"?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - How was it possible to improve the performance in experiment of section 4.2 with 100% of irrelevant classes?
label: asp_substance

sentence: The paper extends previous work on differentiable placticity to include neuro modulation by parameterizing the learning rate of Hebbs update rule.
label: none

sentence: In addition, the authors introduce retroactive modulation that basically allows the system to delay incorporation of plasticity updates via so eligibility traces.
label: none

sentence: Experiments are performaed on 2 simple toy datasets and a simple language modeling task.
label: none

sentence: A newly developed cue-reward association task shows the clear limitations of basic plasticity and how modulation can resolve this.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Slight improvements can also be seen on a simple maze navigation task as well as on a basic language modeling dataset.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Overall I like the motivation, provided background information and simplicity of the approach.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Furthermore, the cue-reward experiment seems to be a well designed show case for neuro-modulation.
label: asp_substance

sentence: However, as the authors acknowledge the overall simplicity of the tasks being evaluated with mostly marginal improvements makes the overall evaluation fall short.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Unfortunately the paper doesn't provide any qualitative analysis on how modulation is employed by the models after training.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Therefore, although I would like to see an extended version of this paper at the conference, without further experiments and analysis I see the current version rather as an interesting workshop contribution.
label: none

sentence: Strengths:
label: none

sentence: - motivation: the natural extension of previous work on differentiable plasticity based on existing knowledge from neuro science is an important next step
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: - cue reward experiment exemplifies limitations of current plasticity approaches and clearly shows the potential benefits of neuro modulation
label: asp_substance

sentence: - maze navigation shows incremental benefits over non-modulated plasticity
label: asp_substance

sentence: - thorough experimentation
label: asp_substance

sentence: - clipping-trick is a neat observation
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Weaknesses:
label: none

sentence: - evaluation: only on toy tasks (which includes PTB), no real world tasks
label: asp_replicability

sentence: - very incremental improvements on PTB over a very simple baseline (far from SotA)
label: asp_replicability

sentence: - evaluated models (feed-forward NNs and LSTMs) are very basic and far from current SotA architectures
label: asp_substance

sentence: - no qualitative analysis on how modulation is actually use by the systems.
label: asp_substance

sentence: E.g., when is modulation strong and when is it not used
label: none

sentence: Comments:
label: none

sentence: - perplexity improvements of less than 1.3 points over plasticity alone (which is the actual baseline for this paper) can hardy be called "significant". Even though they might be statistically significant (meaning nothing more than the two models being statistically different), minor architectural changes can lead to such improvements.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Furthermore PTB is not a "challenging" LM benchmark.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Summary:
label: none

sentence: This paper addresses the computational aspects of Viterbi-based encoding for neural networks.
label: none

sentence: In usual Viterbi codes, input messages are encoded via a convolution with a codeword, and then decoded using a trellis.
label: none

sentence: Now consider a codebook with n convolutional codes, of rate 1/k.
label: none

sentence: Then a vector of length n is represented by inputing a message of length k and receiving n encoded bits.
label: none

sentence: Then the memory footprint (in terms of messages) is reduced by rate k/n.
label: none

sentence: This is the format that will be used to encode the row indices in a matrix, with n columns.

sentence: (The value of each nonzero is stored separately.)
label: none

sentence: However, it is clear that not all messages are possible, only those in the "range space" of my codes. (This part is previous work Lee 2018.)

sentence: The "Double Viterbi" (new contribution) refers to the storage of the nonzero values themselves.

sentence: A weakness of CSR and CSC (carried over to the previous work) is that since each row may have a different number of nonzeros, then finding the value of any particular nonzero requires going through the list to find the right corresponding nonzero, a sequential task.

sentence: Instead, m new Viterbi decompressers are included, where each row becomes (s_1*codeword_1 + s_2*codeword2 + ...) cdot mask, and the new scalar are the results of the linear combinations of the codewords.

sentence: Pros:
label: none

sentence: - I think the work addressed here is important, and though the details are hard to parse and the new contributions seemingly small, it is important enough for practical performance.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: - The idea is theoretically sound and interesting.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Cons:
label: none

sentence: - My biggest issue is that there is no clear evaluation of the runtime benefit of the second Viterbi decompressor.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Compressability is evaluated, but that was already present in the previous work.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Therefore the novel contribution of this paper over Lee 2018 is not clearly outlined.
label: asp_originality

sentence: - It is extremely hard to follow what exactly is going on; I believe a few illustrative examples would help make the paper much clearer; in fact the idea is not that abstract.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: - Minor grammatical mistakes (missing "a" or "the" in front of some terms, suggest proofread.)
label: asp_clarity

sentence: This paper is well set-up to target the interesting problem of degraded generalisation after adversarial training.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: The proposal of applying spectral normalisation (SN) is well motivated, and is supported by margin-based bounds.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: However, the experimental results are weak in justifying the paper's claims.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Pros:
label: none

sentence: * The problem is interesting and well explained
label: asp_clarity

sentence: * The proposed method is clearly motivated
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: * The proposal looks theoretically solid
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Cons:
label: none

sentence: * It is unclear to me whether the "efficient method for SN in convolutional nets" is more efficient than the power iteration algorithm employed in previous work, such as Miyato et al. 2018, which also used SN in conv nets with different strides.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: There is no direct comparison of performance.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: * Fig. 3 needs more explanation.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The horizontal axes are unlabelled, and "margin normalization" is confusing when shown together with SN without an explanation.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Perhaps it's helpful to briefly introduce it in addition to citing Bartlett et al. 2017.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: * The epsilons in Fig. 5 have very different scales (0 - 0.5 vs. 0 - 5). Are these relevant to the specific algorithms and why?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: * Section 5.3 (Fig. 6) is the part most relevant to the generalisation problem.
label: asp_substance

sentence: However, the results are unconvincing: only the results for epsilon = 0.1 are shown, and even so the advantage is marginal.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Furthermore, the baseline models did not use other almost standard regularisation techniques (weight decay, dropout, batch-norm).
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: It is thus unclear whether the advantage can be maintained after applying these standard regularsisers.
label: asp_substance

sentence: A typo in page 6, last line: wth -> with

sentence: This paper proposes to address few-shot learning in a transductive way by learning a label propagation model in an end-to-end manner.
label: none

sentence: Semi-supervised few-shot learning is important considering the limitation of the very few labeled instances.
label: none

sentence: This is an interesting work.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: The merits of this paper lie in the following aspects: (1) It is the first to learn label propagation for transductive few-shot learning.
label: asp_originality

sentence: (2) The proposed approach produced effective empirical results.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The drawbacks  of the work include the following: (1) There is not much technical contribution.
label: asp_substance

sentence: It merely just puts the CNN representation learning and the label propagation together to perform end-to-end learning.
label: none

sentence: Considering the optimization problem involved in the learning process, it is hard to judge whether the effect of such a procedure from the optimization perspective.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: (2) Empirically, it seems TPN achieved very small improvements over the very baseline label propagation.
label: none

sentence: Moreover, the performance reported in this paper seems to be much inferior to the state-of-the-art results reported in the literature.
label: asp_substance

sentence: For example,  on miniImageNet, TADAM(Oreshkin et al, 2018) reported 58.5 (1-shot) and 76.7(5-shot), which are way better than the results reported in this work.
label: none

sentence: This is a major concern.
label: none

sentence: Summary:
label: none

sentence: This paper makes an observation that most of the neural network architectures do not learn the mutual exclusivity (ME) bias: if an object has one label, then it does not need another.
label: none

sentence: Authors demonstrate this in both synthetic tasks and real-world tasks like object recognition and machine translation.
label: none

sentence: Authors argue that ME bias could help the model to handle new classes and rare events better.
label: none

sentence: My comments:
label: none

sentence: I very much enjoyed reading this paper.
label: none

sentence: I support accepting this paper.
label: none

sentence: It highlights one of the missing inductive biases in ML and proposes it as a challenge.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: As the authors also agree, ME bias is missing not just in DNNs.
label: none

sentence: It is the issue of MLE.
label: none

sentence: It would be good to have some non-NN results too.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: I see this is a challenge for MLE than DNNs.
label: none

sentence: 1. In figure-4 you mention that entropy regularizer helps to keep the initial ME score. Can you elaborate more about the way in which entropy regularizer is used with regular MLE training?
label: asp_substance

sentence: 2. It is not very clear how is the base rate computed in Figure 5. I have a guess. But it is better to explain it in detail.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 3. Section 4.2 need more clarity.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: For example, what do you mean by classifying the image as “new”? Is “new” a class name? Also, how is P(N|t) computed? Please explain.
label: none

sentence: 4. Are the authors willing to release the code and data to reproduce the results?
label: asp_substance

sentence: After rebuttal: I have read the authors' response and  I stand by my decision.

sentence: This paper explores self-supervised learning in the low-data regime, comparing results to self-supervised learning on larger datasets.
label: none

sentence: BiGAN, RotNet, and DeepCluster serve as the reference self-supervised methods.
label: none

sentence: It argues that early layers of a convolutional neural network can be effectively learned from a single source image, with data augmentation.
label: none

sentence: A performance gap exists for deeper layers, suggesting that larger datasets are required for self-supervised learning of useful filters in deeper network layers.
label: none

sentence: I believe the primary claim of this paper is neither surprising nor novel.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The long history of successful hand-designed descriptors in computer vision, such as SIFT [Lowe, 1999] and HOG [Dalal and Triggs, 2005], suggest that one can design (with no data at all) features reminiscent of those learned in the first couple layers of a convolutional neural network (local image gradients, followed by characterization of those gradients over larger local windows).
label: none

sentence: More importantly, it is already well established that it is possible to learn, from only a few images, filter sets that resemble the early layers of filters learned by CNNs.
label: none

sentence: This paper fails to account for a vast amount of literature on modeling natural images that predates the post-AlexNet deep-learning era.
label: asp_originality

sentence: For example, see the following paper (over 5600 citations according to Google scholar):
label: none

sentence: [1] Bruno A. Olshausen and David J. Field.
label: none

sentence: Emergence of simple-cell receptive field properties by learning a sparse code for natural images.
label: none

sentence: Nature, 1996.
label: none

sentence: Figure 4 of [1] shows results for learning 16x16 filters using "ten 512x512 images of natural scenes".
label: none

sentence: Compare to the conv1 filters in Figure 2 of the paper under review.
label: none

sentence: This 1996 paper clearly established that it is possible to learn such filters from a small number of images.
label: none

sentence: There is long history of sparse coding and dictionary learning techniques, including multilayer representations, that follows from the early work of [1].
label: none

sentence: The paper should at minimum engage with this extensive history, and, in light of it, explain whether its claims are actually novel.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The authors proposed meta domain adaptation to address domain shift scenario in meta learning setup.
label: none

sentence: The proposed model combines few shot meta-learning with the adversarial domain adaptation to demonstrate performance improvements in several experiments.
label: none

sentence: Pros:
label: none

sentence: 1. A new few shot learning with domain shift problem is studied in the paper.
label: asp_originality

sentence: 2. A new model combining prototypical network with GAN and cycle-consistency loss for addressing meta-learning domain shift scenario.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The experimental improvements on omniglot seem quite substantial.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Cons:
label: none

sentence: 1. Can you clarify why the proposed approach is better than the Meta-RevGrad baseline?
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: It seems that both are using meta-learning with domain adaptation technique.
label: none

sentence: What happen for Meta-RevGrad + idt or Meta-RevGrad + revMap?
label: asp_substance

sentence: I feel the baseline in domain adaptation area is a bit limited.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 2. How is the performance of a simpler baseline such as combining a subset of new domain as training set to train MAML or PN (probably in 5-shot, 5-class case)?
label: asp_substance

sentence: 3. It seems the domain shift in the paper is less dramatic.
label: none

sentence: i.e., omniglot <-> omniglot-M. I wonder whether the proposed approach can still work in large domain shift such as omniglot to fashion-mnist etc.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 4. The novelty of the model is relatively limited as it is a combination of previous techniques on a new problem.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Minor:
label: none

sentence: 1. Where is L_da in Figure 2? In Figure 2, what’s the unlabelled data from which testing tasks are drawn? Is it from meta-test data training set?
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 2. In the caption of figure 2, there should be a space after `":".
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The paper presents a way to learn a vectorial representation for items which are only described by triplet similiarity expressions.
label: none

sentence: The paper not only claims 'large scale representation learning' but also utilizing the described idea to use neural networks to "directly, approximately solve non-convex NP-hard optimization problems that arise naturally in unsupervised learning problems." Both claims are not really shown in the paper: (i) The experiments are not large scale and (ii)  it becomes not clear how any substantiate insight with respect to NP-hard problems can be gained here apart from the fact that it tackles a ML problem, which many seem to be computationally hard problems.
label: asp_substance

sentence: As such the paper is not convincing.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: On a more detailed level it is not clear why the log n representation for items is choosen -- why not just map to embeddings directly?
label: none

sentence: The more interesting question of how to generalize to unseen items (how would that be possible given that items have no representation at all) is not discussed at all and seems not to be realizable, which makes the starting point of such methods (items have no representation) questionable.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The paper also misses relevant citations of similar questions from the field of (probabilistic) matrix factorization and relational learning.
label: arg_other

sentence: The authors introduce a  novel  on-policy  temporally  consistent  exploration  strategy, named Neural  AdaptiveDropout Policy Exploration (NADPEx), for deep reinforcement learning agents.
label: none

sentence: The main idea is to sample from a distribution of plausible subnetworks modeling the temporally consistent exploration.
label: none

sentence: For this, the authors use the ideas of the standard dropout for deep networks.
label: none

sentence: Using the proposed  dropout transformation that is differentiable, the authors show that the KL regularizers on policy-space play an important role in stabilizing its learning.
label: none

sentence: The experimental validation is performed on continuous control learning tasks, showing the benefits of the proposed.
label: none

sentence: This paper is very well written, although very dense and not easy to follows, as many methods are referenced and assume that the reviewer is highly familiar with the related works.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: This poses a challenge in evaluating this paper.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Nevertheless, this paper clearly explores and offers a novel approach for more efficient on-policy exploration which allows for more stable learning compared to traditional approaches.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Even though the authors answer positively to each of their four questions in the experiments section
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: it would like that the authors provide more intuition why these improvements occur and also outline the limitations of their approach.
label: none

sentence: The paper proposes a technique to perform reasoning on mathematical formulas in a latent space.
label: none

sentence: The model is trained to predict whether a rewrite rule can be applied to a formula given its latent representation.
label: none

sentence: When the rewrite is possible, the model also predicts the embedding of the resulting formula.
label: none

sentence: Experiments show that the network can be applied multiple steps in a row, while operating only in the embedding space.
label: none

sentence: 1. As mentioned in the paragraph before Section 4.1, it would be much simpler to consider a single latent embedding space L. In that case, \sigma and \alpha become unnecessary and we only need to train \omega.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Did you try to have a single network?
label: asp_substance

sentence: This seems a much more natural approach to me, and I'm surprised that you did not start with that.
label: asp_substance

sentence: From my experience, aligning embedding spaces is something that usually does not work very well, especially in high dimension.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The role of \sigma seems very redundant given \omega.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 2. If you consider \sigma, why do you also predict the rewrite success with \omega? Couldn't it be simply a function from S x S -> L ?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 3. The graph neural networks used in the model are not described in the paper, only a reference to Paliwal et al (2019) is given.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: It would be helpful to have a brief paragraph describing this architecture, for readers not familiar with the referenced paper.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 4. How large is the training set of (T, P) pairs? I don't think this is mentioned in the paper.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 5. To train \sigma and \omega, the negative instances are selected randomly.
label: none

sentence: You mention that negative mining should improve over this strategy. What does negative mining correspond to in this context? Are there bad rewrites better than others?
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 6. Did you consider using an inverse function (say G), that maps an embedding in L / L' back to S (i.e. the inverse function of gamma / gamma').
label: asp_substance

sentence: I would imagine that even if an embedding X is a bit noisy, because not exactly equal to gamma(P) where P is the expression it represents, you could consider doing the propagation with gamma(G(X)).
label: asp_substance

sentence: This could be a possibility to remove the noise you have when doing multi-step operations (and potentially go way beyond 4 steps).
label: none

sentence: Also, G could be used to check whether you obtain the expected formula after 4 steps, which would be a more informative information than the L2 distance between the resulting embedding and the embedding of the final formula.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Overall, the model is a bit complicated (e.g. question 1.), but the results are promising, the paper is well written, and the ability to manipulate formula embeddings is probably going to be useful in the context of theorem proving.
label: asp_substance

sentence: This paper studies the dynamics-based curiosity intrinsic reward where the agent is rewarded highly in states where the forward dynamic prediction errors are high in an embedding space (either due to complexity of the state or unfamiliarity).
label: none

sentence: Overall I like the paper, it's systematic and follows a series of practical considerations and step-by-step experimentations.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: One of the main area which is missing in the paper is the comparison to two other class of RL methods: count-based exploration and novelty search.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: While the section 4 has a discussion on related papers, there's no systematic experimental comparison across these methods.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: In sec. 4, there's a reference to an initial set of experiments with count-based methods without much details.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Another area of improvement is the experiments around VAE.
label: asp_substance

sentence: While the paper shows experimentally that they aren't as successful as the RFs or IDFs, there's no further discussion on the reasons for poor performance.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Also it's not clear from the details in the paper what are the architectures for the VAE and RFs (there's a reference to the code but would've been better to have sufficient details in the paper).
label: asp_clarity

sentence: An interesting area for future work could be on early stopping techniques for embedding training - it seems that RFs perform well without any training while in some scenarios the IDFs work overall the best.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: So it would be interesting to explore how much training is needed for the embedding model.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: RFs are never trained and IDFs are continuously trained.
label: none

sentence: So maybe somewhere in between could be the sweet spot with training for a short while and then fixing the features.
label: none

sentence: This paper proposes two new architectures for processing set-structured data: An RNN with an accumulator on its output, and an RNN with gating followed by an accumulator on its output.
label: none

sentence: While sensible, this seems to me to be too minor a contribution to stand alone as a paper.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Additionally, I believe the experimental tasks are new, and as a result all implementations of competing techniques are by the paper authors. This makes it difficult to have confidence in the higher reported performance of the proposed techniques.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Algorithms for Streaming data using a machine learning oracle is analyzed theoretically and empirically.
label: none

sentence: The idea is to build on some recent work (Hsu 19) which used RNNs to predict heavy hitters in streaming data.
label: none

sentence: The purpose of this paper is to analyze whether such an oracle can help streaming algorithms to obtain improved bounds.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: I am not very familiar with this line of research so my comments will be more general in this case.
label: none

sentence: The idea of improved bounds for streaming algorithms using machine learning oracle seems to be very appealing to me.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The authors present novel theoretical results supporting this.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Experiments are performed on real as well as synthetic datasets using Hsu et al.’s method as an oracle.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Two real-world problems are selected, i.e., distinct packets in a network flow, Number of occurrences of each type of search query, and it is shown that using a oracle improves performance as compared to methods that do not use the oracle.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Overall, I think the paper seems to be  an interesting direction which has both formal guarantees and experiments validating them in real-world datasets.

sentence: One issue is perhaps, very little in terms of related work.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: I am not sure if this is the first work in this direction of proving bounds assuming an oracle or if there is some background work that the authors could provide to put this into context.

sentence: The paper proposed to use a prior distribution to constraint the network embedding.
label: none

sentence: The paper used very restricted Gaussian distributions for the formulation.

sentence: The proposed approach should compared to other stronger methods such as graph convolution neural network/message passing neural networks/structure2vec.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: This work is clearly the work of a large team.

sentence: the paper clearly defines what is being done.

sentence: I have spent a lot of effort with MCTS. I can not find the corresponding allowance for stochastic jumps in the latent space long horizon learning.

sentence: You are heavy on the machinery and math. I find the learning in the latent space the important part and there are things like how much simulation is done in the latent learning not clearly spelled out. How does the effort compare to the 1E9 steps of the base line your refer to?

sentence: Your team is highly competent your style is distinct.

sentence: Now may be the time to move you to understanding what structures get learned in latent space, are the in fact compact, diverse?

sentence: Perhaps there is room for memory/memories in the latent space?

sentence: * Summary
label: none

sentence: The paper proposes an improved method for computing derivatives of the expectation.
label: none

sentence: Such problems arises with many probabilistic models with noises or latent variables.
label: none

sentence: The paper proposes a new gradient estimator of low variance applicable in certain scenarios, in particular it allows training of generative models in which observations and/or latent variables are discrete.
label: none

sentence: The submission clearly improves the state-of-the-art, experimentally demonstrates the method on several problems comparing with the alternative techniques.
label: asp_substance

sentence: In what concerns the optimization, the method achieves a better objective value much faster, confirming that it is a lower variance gradient estimator.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The clarity of the presentation (in particular the description of when the method is applicable) and the technical correctness of the paper are somewhat lacking.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: In terms of applicability, it seems that many cases where discrete latent variables would be really interesting are not covered (e.g. sigmoid belief networks); the paper demonstrates experiments with discrete images (binary or 4-bit) not particularly motivated in my opinion.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: It also contains lots of additional technical details and experiments in the appendix, which I unfortunately did not review.
label: arg_other

sentence: Clarity
label: none

sentence: In the abstract the paper promises more than it delivers.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Many problems can be cast as optimizing an expectation-based objective.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The result does not at all apply to all of them.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: The reparameterization trick does not apply to all continuous random variables, only to such that the reparameterization satisfies certain smoothness conditions.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Discrete variables are supported by the method only in the case that the distribution factors over all discrete variables conditionally on any additional “continuous variables” (to which the reparameterization trick is applicable).
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: This very much limits the utility of the method.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: In particular it is not applicable to learning e.g. sigmoid belief networks [Neal, 92] (with conditional Bernoulli units) and many other problems.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: “reparametrizable distributions”
label: none

sentence: A Bernoulli(p) random variable is discrete, yet it is reparametrizable as [Z>p] with Z following standard logistic distribution, whose density and cdf is smooth.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Because of the above many discussions about discrete vs. continuous variables are missleading.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Section 2.
label: none

sentence: The notation of the true distribution as “q” the model as p and the approximate posterior of the model as “q” again is inconsistent.

label: asp_clarity

sentence: For the purpose of introduction, it might be better to give examples of expectation objectives such as:
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: - dropout: q is the distribution of NN outputs given the input image and integrating out latent dropout noises, gamma are parameters of this NN.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: - VAE, GAN: q is the generative model defined as a mapping of a standard multivariate normal distribution by a NN.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: - sigmoid belief networks: q is a Bayesian network where each conditional distribution is a logistic regression model.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Then to state to which of these cases the results of the paper are applicable, allow for an improvement of the variance and at what additional computational cost (considering the cost of evaluating the discrete derivatives).
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: This paper proposes variational selective autoencoders (VSAE) to learn the joint distribution model of full data (both observed and unobserved modalities) and the mask information from arbitrary partial-observation data.
label: none

sentence: To infer latent variables from partial-observation data, they introduce the selective proposal distribution that switches encoders depending on whether each input modality is observed.
label: none

sentence: This paper is well written, and the method proposed in this paper is nice.
