sentence: Comments:
label: none

sentence: - The authors state that x_j is sampled from the "prior network" to calculate E_x_j in Equation 10, but I didn’t understand how this network is set up. Could you explain it in detail?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - The authors claim that adding p(m|z) to the objective function (i.e., generating m from the decoder) allows the latent variable to have mask information.
label: none

sentence: However, I don’t know how effective this is in practice.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Specifically, how performance differs compared to when p (m | z) is not used and the decoder p (x | z, m) is conditioned by the mask included in the training set instead of the generated mask?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - Why did you not do image inpainting in higher-dimensional experiments like Ivanov et al. (2019), i.e., considering each pixel as a different modality? Of course, I know that Ivanov et al. require the full data as input during training, but I’m interested in whether VSAE can perform inpainting properly even if trained given imperfect images.
label: asp_substance

sentence: This paper proposes using spectral normalization (SN) as a regularization for adversarial training, which is based on [Miyato et. al., ICLR 2018], where the original paper used SN for GAN training.
label: none

sentence: The paper also uses the results from [Neyshabur et. al., ICLR 2018], where the original paper provided generalization bounds that depends on spectral norm of each layer.
label: none

sentence: The paper is well written in general, the experiments are extensive.
label: none

sentence: The idea of studying based on the combination of the results from two previous papers is quite natural, since one uses spectral normalization in practice for GAN training, and the other provides generalization bound that depends on spectral norm.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The novelty of the algorithm itself is limited, since GAN and adversarial training are both minmax problems, and the original algorithm can be carried over easily.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The experimental result itself is quite comprehensive.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: On the other hand, this paper provides specific generalization bounds under three adversarial attack methods, which explains the power of SN under those settings.
label: asp_substance

sentence: However, it is not clear to me that these are some novel results that can better help adversarial training.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The paper proposes a method to do math reasoning purely using formula embeddings.
label: none

sentence: The proposed method employs a graph neural network to embed math formulas to a latent space.
label: none

sentence: The formula embeddings are then combined with theorem embeddings (also formulas, computed in the same way as formula embeddings) to predict whether one can do one step of math reasoning using the corresponding theorem, and also to predict the embeddings of the resulting formula.
label: none

sentence: Empirically the authors demonstrate that the method can be chained end-to-end to do multiple steps of reasoning purely in the latent space.
label: none

sentence: I tend to accept this paper, (but also OK if it gets rejected), for the following reasons: (1) the idea is novel and interesting; (2) the writing of the paper is below conference standard and very hard to read, especially the method and the experiment sections.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Novelty and significance
label: none

sentence: I really like the idea of doing math reasoning in latent space.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The idea is definitely novel and interesting.
label: asp_originality

sentence: It is related to existing works such as neural logic induction[1] and planning in latent space[2].
label: none

sentence: It is amazing that one can do multiple steps of math reasoning after only training the model using data from one single step.
label: asp_originality

sentence: It would be interesting to see how it can improve existing learning-based theorem provers.
label: asp_substance

sentence: My question is if we want to integrate the proposed method into theorem provers, after multiple steps of math reasoning, how would us know the goal has been proved? Is it possible that we can train a decoder that maps back from the latent space to the formula space?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Also can it work with theorems that decompose the current goal into several sub-goals?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: I know these are not the concerns of this paper, but I would be really grateful if you could provide some intuitive answers!
label: none

sentence: Writing
label: none

sentence: The paper is not well-organized and not written in a consistent way. For the method and the experiment sections, I need to jump back and forth several times in order to understand what the authors are trying to say.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 1. Typo: Third paragraph in section 1, "...which is makes use of ...".
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 2. It's very confusing when the authors introduce \sigma and \omega in the beginning of section 4: why would you need two networks predict the same thing?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 3. Mentioning "merging \sigma and \omega, is left for future work" is confusing before formally introducing \sigma and \omega.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 4. Even when the authors formally introduce \sigma and \omega in 4.2, it is still not clear that why both of them are used for modelling the success probability.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 5. In fact, I don't know why \omega needs to output p. It's never mentioned in the experiment section.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 6. The rationale of the two tower design (why not combine two) is not clearly explained.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 7. Typo: Page 5 last paragraph, "... negative instances for for each ...".
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 8. The itemized part in 5.3, "...carefully selected baselines: 1.xxx, 2.xxx, 3. xxx, 4. xxx". However, both 3 and 4 are not baselines!
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 9. It is not clear that baseline 1 and 2 correspond to which baselines in later experiments.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 10. Reading the baselines before the experiments is very confusing.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: For example, for baseline 1, it is very hard to understand why would we want to use such an unusual baseline, and why it is called a "random baseline".
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 11. Baseline 2 is actually referred to as "usage baseline" but this name is not introduced in the itemized part.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: [1] Rocktäschel, Tim, and Sebastian Riedel. "End-to-end differentiable proving." Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems. 2017.
label: none

sentence: [2] Srinivas, Aravind, et al. "Universal planning networks." arXiv preprint arXiv:1804.00645 (2018).
label: none

sentence: This paper proposes an extension to the continual learning framework using existing variational continual learning (VCL) as the base method.
label: none

sentence: In particular, it proposes to use the weight of evidence (WE) (from Zintgraf et al 2017) for each task.
label: none

sentence: Firstly, this WE can be used to visualize the learned model (as used in Zintgraf et. al. 2017).
label: none

sentence: The novelty of this paper is:
label: none

sentence: 1. to use this WE from the current task to generate a silence map (by smoothing the WE) for the next task.
label: none

sentence: This is interpreted the learned the learned attention region.
label: none

sentence: Such an approach is named Interpretable COntinual Learning (ICL)
label: none

sentence: 2. The paper proposes a metric for the saliency map naming FSM which is an extension of existing metric SSR.
label: none

sentence: The extension is to take pixel count to compute the area instead of using rectangular region area, as well as taking the distance between pixels into account.
label: none

sentence: This metric can be used to evaluate the level of catastrophic forgetting.
label: none

sentence: Pro:
label: none

sentence: In general, the idea is very intuitive and make sense.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: The paper also demonstrates superior performance with the proposed method on continual learning on all classic tasks comparing with VCL and EWC.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The presentation is very easy to follow.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: It seems like a valid and flexible extension that can be used in other continual learning frameworks.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Cons:
label: none

sentence: The theoretical contribution is very limited.
label: asp_originality

sentence: The work is rather incremental from current state-of-the-art methods.
label: asp_originality

sentence: There should be a better discussion of related work on the topic.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: The paper currently only mentions the most related work for the proposed method,  using the whole section 2 to describe VCL and use section 3 to describe FSM and half of section 5 to describe SSR.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: A general overview of related work in these directions are needed.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Other:
label: none

sentence: 1. The paper should also consider more recently proposed evaluation metrics such as discussed in https://arxiv.org/pdf/1805.09733.pdf
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 2. The author should try to avoid using yellow color in plots.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Update 11/21
label: none

sentence: With the additional experiments (testing a new image, testing fine-tuning of hand-crafted features), additions to related work, and clarifications, I am happy to raise my score to accept.
label: none

sentence: Overall, I think this paper is a nice sanity check on recent self-supervision methods.
label: asp_substance

sentence: In the future, I am quite curious about how these mono-image learned features would fare on more complex downstream tasks (e.g., segmentation, keypoint detection) which necessarily rely less on texture.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: Summary
label: none

sentence: This paper seeks to understand the role of the *number of training examples* in self-supervised learning with images.
label: none

sentence: The usefulness of the learned features is evaluated with linear probes at each layer for either ImageNet or CiFAR image classification.
label: none

sentence: Empirically, they find that a single image along with heavy data augmentation suffices for learning the first 2-3 layers of convolutional weights, while later layers improve with more self-supervised training images.
label: none

sentence: The result holds for three state-of-the-art self-supervised methods, tested with two single-image training examples.
label: none

sentence: In my view, learning without labels is an important problem, and it is interesting what can be learned from a single image and simple data augmentation strategies.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Comments / Questions
label: none

sentence: It seems to me that for completeness, Table 4 should include the result of training a supervised network on top of random conv1/2 and Scattering network features, because this experiment is actually testing what we want - performance of the features when fine-tuned for a downstream task.
label: asp_substance

sentence: So for example, even if a linear classifier on top of Scattering features does poorly, if downstream fine-tuning results in the same performance as another pre-training method, then Scattering is a perfectly fine approach for initial features.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Could the authors please either correct this logic or provide the experiments?
label: none

sentence: Further, it seems that the results in Table 4 might be a bit obscured by the size of the downstream task dataset.
label: asp_substance

sentence: I wonder if the learned features require fewer fully supervised images to obtain the same performance on the downstream task?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Can the authors clarify how the neural style transfer experiment is performed?
label: asp_substance

sentence: The method from Gatys et al. requires features from different layers of the feature hierarchy, including deeper layers.
label: none

sentence: Are all these features taken directly from the self-supervised network or is it fine-tuned in some way?
label: asp_substance

sentence: While I appreciate the computational burden of testing more images, it does feel that Image A and B are quite cherry-picked in being very visually diverse.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Because of this, it seems like a precise answer to what makes a good single training image remains unknown.
label: asp_substance

sentence: I wonder how feasible it is to find a proxy metric that corresponds to the performance on downstream tasks which is expensive to compute.
label: asp_substance

sentence: It might be interesting to try to generate synthetic images (or modify real ones) that are good for this purpose and observe their properties.
label: asp_substance

sentence: I disagree with the claim of practicality in the introduction (page 2, top).
label: asp_substance

sentence: While training on one image does reduce the burden of number of images, the computational burden remains the same. And as mentioned above, it doesn’t seem likely that *any* image would work for this method.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Finally, more images are needed to learn the deeper layers for the downstream task anyway.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The paper is well-written and clear.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The paper design a low variance gradient for distributions associated with continuous or discrete random variables.
label: none

sentence: The gradient is designed in the way to approximate the  property of reparameterization gradient.
label: none

sentence: The paper is comprehensive and includes mathematical details.
label: none

sentence: I have following comments/questions
label: none

sentence: 1. What is the \kappa in “variable-nabla” stands for? What is the gradient w.r.t. \kappa?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 2. In Eq(8), does the outer expectation w.r.t . y_{-v} be approximated by one sample? If so, it is using the local expectation method.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: How does that differs from Titsias & Lazaro-Gredilla(2015) both mathematically and experimentally?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 3. Assume y_v is M-way categorical distribution, Eq(8) evaluates f by 2*V*M times which can be computationally expensive.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: What is the computation complexity of GO? How to explain the fast speed shown in the experiments?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 4. A most simple way to reduce the variance of REINFORCE gradient is to take multiple Monte-Carlo samples at the cost of more computation with multiple function f evaluations.
label: none

sentence: Assume GO gradient needs to evaluate f N times, how does the performance compared with the REINFORCE gradient with N Monte-Carlo samples?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 5. In the discrete VAE experiment, upon brief checking the results in Grathwohl(2017), it shows validation ELBO for MNIST as (114.32,111.12), OMNIGLOT as (122.11,128.20) from which two cases are better than GO.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Does the hyper parameter setting favor the GO gradient in the reported experiments?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Error bar may also be needed for comparison.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: What about the performance of GO gradient in the 2 stochastic layer setting in Grathwohl(2017)?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 6. The paper claims GO has less parameters than REBAR/RELAX. But in Figure 9, GO has more severe overfitting. How to explain this contradicts between the model complexity and overfitting?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The paper proposes a few variations on the RGCN model with adding attention to either within relations or across relations.
label: none

sentence: Unfortunately the paper falls short in two main areas:
label: none

sentence: - novelty: the additions proposed are small modifications to existing algorithms and there are other methods of attention on graphs which have been discussed in the paper but not directly compared to (e.g. this method builds heavily on Velickovic et al 2017)
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: - impact: the results achieved in the experiments are very small improvements compared to the baseline of RGCN (~ +0.01 in two experiments and ~ -0.04 in another) and often these small variations in results can be compensated with better baselines training (e.g. better hyper-params, ...)
label: asp_substance

sentence: However, on a positive note, the paper has been written very well and I really liked the frank discussion on page 8 about results on MUTAG dataset.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: This paper proposes a self-auxiliary-training method that aims to improve the generalization performance of simple supervised learning.
label: none

sentence: The basic idea is to train the classification network to predict fine-level auxiliary labels in addition to the ground-truth coarse label, where the auxiliary labels used in training is generated by a generator network.
label: none

sentence: During training, the classification network and the generator network are alternatively updated, and the update of the latter aims to maximize the improvement of the former after using the generated auxiliary label for training.
label: none

sentence: The method requires a class hierarchy in advance to define the binary mask applied to the output layer for auxiliary class prediction.
label: none

sentence: A KL divergence term is attached to the optimization objective to avoid generating trivial and collapsing auxiliary classes.
label: none

sentence: Pros:
label: none

sentence: 1) The main idea is simple and easy to understand.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 2) It discusses the class collapsing problem in generating pseudo (auxiliary) labels and provides a reasonable solution, i.e., using KL divergence as regularization.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 3) Uses several visualizations to show experimental results.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Cons:
label: none

sentence: 1) The problem it aims to solve is neither multi-task learning nor meta-learning: it tries to solve a supervised classification problem defined on principle classes, with the help of simultaneously predicting/generating auxiliary class labels.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Although the concept of "task" is not explicitly defined in this paper, the authors seem to associate each task with a specific class.
label: asp_substance

sentence: This is not correct: in meta-learning, each task is a subset of classes drawn from a ground set of classes, and different tasks are independently sampled.
label: none

sentence: In addition, the classification models for different tasks are independent, though their training might be related by a meta-learner.
label: none

sentence: Hence, the claims in multiple places of this paper and the names for the two networks are misleading.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: 2) At the end of Page 4, the authors show that the update of the generator only depends on the improvement of the classifier after using the auxiliary label for training.
label: none

sentence: In fact, the optimal auxiliary labels minimizing the objective is the ground truth label for principle classes.
label: none

sentence: This results in the class collapsing problem observed by the authors.
label: none

sentence: The KL divergence regularization introduces extra randomness to the auxiliary labels and thus mitigates the problem, but it hardly provides any useful information except randomness.
label: asp_substance

sentence: In other words, the auxiliary labels for a specific principle class are very possible to be multiple noisy copies of the principal label with random perturbations.
label: none

sentence: So it is not convincing to me that the auxiliary labels generated by the generator can be really helpful.
label: none

sentence: My conjecture is that the observed improvements are mainly due to the softness of the auxiliary labels, which has been proved by model compression/knowledge distillation and recent "born-again neural networks".
label: none

sentence: To verify this, the authors might need to compare the results with those methods (which use the generated soft probability of ground truth classes for training), and the "random-noisy copies of soft principle label" mentioned above.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 3) The experiments lack comparisons to several important baselines from self-supervised learning community, and methods using soft labels for training (as mentioned in 2) above).
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: A successful idea of self-supervised learning is to use the output feature map of the trained classification network to generate auxiliary training signals, since it provides extra information about the learned distance beyond the ground-truth labels.
label: none

sentence: The authors might want to compare to "Mathilde Caron, Piotr Bojanowski, Armand Joulin, and Matthijs Douze.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Deep Clustering for Unsupervised Learning of Visual Features. ECCV 2018." and "Carl Doersch and Andrew Zisserman. Multi-task self-supervised visual learning. ICCV 2017." Moreover, since the method is not a meta-learning approach for few-shot learning, it is not fair and also not appropriate to compare with Prototypical Network.
label: none

sentence: 4) Although the paper claims that the ground truth fine labels are not required, it requires a class hierarchy, which in the experiments are provided by the dataset and defined between true coarse and fine classes.
label: none

sentence: In practice, such hierarchy might be much harder to achieve than the primary (coarse) labels, and might be as costly to obtain as the true fine-class labels.
label: asp_substance

sentence: This weakens the feasibility of the proposed method.
label: none

sentence: 5) The experiments only test the proposed method on CIFAR100 and CIFAR10, which has at most 100 fine classes.
label: none

sentence: It is necessary to test it on datasets with much more fine classes and much-complicated hierarchy, e.g., ImageNet, MS COCO or their subsets, which have ideal class hierarchy structures.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: Minor comments:
label: none

sentence: Some important equations in the paper should be numbered.
label: asp_substance

sentence: This paper proposes an approach for automatic robot design based on Neural graph evolution.
label: none

sentence: The overall approach has a flavor of genetical algorithms, as it also performs evolutionary operations on the graph, but it also allows for a better mechanism for policy sharing across the different topologies, which is nice.
label: none

sentence: My main concern about the paper is that, currently, the experiments do not include any strong baseline (the ES currently is not a strong baseline, see comments below).
label: asp_substance

sentence: The experiments currently demonstrate that optimizing both controller and hardware is better than optimizing just the controller, which is not surprising and is a phenomenon which has been previously studied in the literature.
label: asp_originality

sentence: What instead is missing is an answer to the question: Is it worth using a neural graph? what are the advantages and disadvantages compared to previous approaches?
label: asp_substance

sentence: I would like to see additional experiments to answer this questions.
label: asp_substance

sentence: In particular, I believe that any algorithms you compare against, you should optimize both G and theta, since optimizing purely the hardware is unfair.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: You should use an existing ES implementation (e.g., from some well-known package) instead of a naive implementation, and as additional baseline also CMA-ES.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: If you can also compare against one or two algorithms of your choice from the recent literature it would also give more value to the comparison.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Detailed comments:
label: none

sentence: - in the abstract you say that "NGE is the first algorithm that can automatically discover complex robotic graph structures".
label: none

sentence: This statement is ambiguous and potentially unsupported by evidence. how do you define complex? that can or that did discover?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - in the introduction you mention that automatic robot design had limited success.
label: none

sentence: This is rather subject, and I would tend to disagree.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Moreover, the same limitations that apply to other algorithms to make them successful, in my opinion, apply to your proposed algorithm (e.g., difficulty to move from simulated to real-world).
label: none

sentence: - The digression at the bottom of the first page about neural architecture search seem out of context and interrupts the flow of the introduction.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: What is the point that you are trying to make? Also, note that some of the algorithms that you are citing there have indeed applied beyond architecture search, eg. Bayesian optimization is used for gait optimization in robotics, and Genetic algorithms have been used for automatic robot design.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - The stated contributions number 3 and 5 are not truly contributions.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: #3 is so generic that a large part of the previous literature on the topic fall under this category -- not new.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: #5 is weak, and tell us more about the limitations of random search and naive ES than necessarily a merit of your approach.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - Sec 2.2: "(GNNs) are very effective" effective at what? what is the metric that you consider?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - Sec 3 "(PS), where weights are reused" can you already go into more details or refer to later sections?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - First line page 4 you mention AF, without introducing the acronym ever before.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: - Sec 3.1: the statements about MB and MF algorithms are inaccurate.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Model-based RL algorithms can work in real-time (e.g. http://proceedings.mlr.press/v78/drews17a/drews17a.pdf) and have been shown to have same asymptotic performance of MB controllers for simple robot control (e.g. https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.12114)
label: none

sentence: - "to speed up and trade off between evaluating fitness and evolving new species" Unclear sentence. speed up what
label: asp_clarity

sentence: ? why is this a trade-off?
label: none

sentence: - Sec 3.4 can you recap all the parameters after eq.11? going through Sec 3.2 and 2.2 to find them is quite annoying.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: would argue that computational cost is rarely a concern among evolutionary algorithms.
label: none

sentence: The cost of evaluating the function is typically more pressing, and as a result it is important to have algorithms that can converge within a small number of iterations/generations.
label: none

sentence: - Providing the same computational budget seem rather arbitrary at the moment, and it heavily depends from implementation. How many evaluations do you perform for each method? why not having the same budget of experiments?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Summary:
label: none

sentence: The manuscript proposes a modification of generators in GANs which improves performance under two popular metrics for multiple architectures, loss, benchmarks, regularizers, and hyperparameter settings.
label: none

sentence: Using the conditional batch normalization mechanism, the input noise vector is allowed to modulate layers of the generator.
label: none

sentence: As this modulation only depends on the noise vector, this technique does not require additional annotations.
label: none

sentence: In addition to the extensive experimentation on different settings showing performance improvements, the authors also present an ablation study, that shows the impact of the method when applied to different layers.
label: none

sentence: Strengths:
label: none

sentence: - The idea is simple.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The experimentation is extensive and results are convincing in that they show a clear improvement in performance using the method in a large majority of settings.
label: asp_substance

sentence: - I also like the ablation study showing the impact of the method applied at different layers.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Requests for clarification/additional information:
label: none

sentence: - I might have missed that, but are the authors offering an interpretation of their observation that the performance of the self-modulation model performs worse in the combination of spectral normalization and the SNDC architecture?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - The ablation study shows that the impact is highest when modulation is applied to the last layer (if only one layer is modulated).
label: none

sentence: It seems modulation on layer 4 comes in as a close second.
label: none

sentence: I am curious about why that might be.
label: asp_substance

sentence: - I would like to see some more interpretation on why this method works.
label: asp_substance

sentence: - Did the authors inspect generated samples of the baseline and the proposed method? Is there a notable qualitative difference?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Overall, the idea is simple, the explanation is clear and experimentation is extensive. I would like to see more commentary on why this method might have long-term impact (or not).
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: This paper is an empirical contribution regarding SGD arguing that it presents two different behaviors which the authors name a noise dominated regimen, and a curvature dominated regime.
label: none

sentence: They observe that the behaviors seem to arise in different batch sizes
label: none

sentence: The authors derive empirical conclusions and perform experiments in different settings.
label: none

sentence: The paper is well-written and the experimental setup seems to be carefully carried out.
label: asp_substance

sentence: I find the observations interesting, but the contribution is empirical and not entirely new. It would be nice if there were some theoretical results to back up the observations.
label: asp_originality

sentence: This paper aims to estimate time-delayed, nonlinear causal influences from time series under the causal sufficiency assumption.
label: none

sentence: It is easy to follow and contains a lot of empirical results.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Thanks for the results, but I have several questions.
label: none

sentence: First, In Theorem 2, which seems to be a main result of the paper, the authors were concerned with the condition when W_{ji} >0, but there is not conclusion if W_{ji} =0.
label: asp_substance

sentence: In order to correctly estimate causal relations from data, both cases must be considered.
label: none

sentence: Second, the conclusion of Theorem 2 seems to be flawed.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Let me try to make it clear with the following example.
label: none

sentence: Suppose x^1_{t-2} directly causes x^2_{t-1} and that x^2_{t-1} directly causes x^3_{t}, without a direct influence from x^1_{t-2}  to x^3_{t}. Then when minimizing (2), we have the following results step by step:
label: none

sentence: 1) The noise standard deviation in x^2_{t-1}, denoted by \eta_2, may be non-zero.
label: none

sentence: This is because we minimize a tradeoff of the prediction error (the first term in (2)) and a function of the reciprocal of the noise standard deviation \eta_2 (the second term in (2)), not only the prediction error.
label: none

sentence: 2) If \eta_2 is non-zero, then x^1_{t-2} will be useful for the purpose of predicting x^3_{t}. (Note that if \eta_2 is zero, then x^1_{t-2} is not useful for predicting x^3_{t).) From the d-separation perspective, this is because x^1_{t-2} and x^3_{t} are not d-separated by x^2_{t-1} + \eta_2 \cdot \epsilon_2, although they are d-separated by x^2_{t-1}. Then the causal Markov condition tells use that x^1_{t-2} and x^3_{t} are not independent conditional on x^2_{t-1} + \eta_2 \cdot \epsilon_2, which means that x^1_{t-2} is useful for predicting x^3_{t}.
label: none

sentence: 3) Given that x^1_{t-2} is useful for predicting x^3_{t}, when (2) is minimized, \eta_1 will not go to infinity, resulting in a non-zero W_{13), which *mistakenly* tells us that X^{1}_{t-1} directly structurally causes x^{(3)}_t.
label: none

sentence: This illustrates that the conclusion of Theorem 2 may be wrong.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: I believe this is because the proof of Theorem 2 is flawed in lines 5-6 on Page 16.
label: none

sentence: It does not seem sensible to drop X^{j}_{t-1} + \eta_X \cdot \epsilon_X and attain a smaller value of the cost function at the same time.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Please carefully check it, especially the argument given in lines 10-13.
label: none

sentence: Third, it is rather surprising that the authors didn't mention anything about the traditional causal discovery methods based on conditional independence relations in the data, known as constraint-based methods, such as the PC algorithm (Spirtes et al., 1993), IC algorithm (Pearl, 2000), and FCI (Spirtes et al., 1993).
label: asp_substance

sentence: Such methods are directly applicable to time-delayed causal relations by further considering the constraint that effects temporally follow the causes.
label: none

sentence: Fourth, please make it clear that the proposed method aims to estimate "causality-in-mean" because of the formulation in terms of regression.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: For instance, if x^j_{t-1} influences only the variance of x^i_{t}, but not its mean, then the proposed method may not detect such a causal influence, although the constraint-based methods can.
label: none

sentence: Any response would be highly appreciated.
label: none

sentence: The recent work of Schott et al (which the authors compare results to) proposed the use of Bayes rule inversion as a more robust mechanism for classification under different types of adversarial attacks.
label: none

sentence: The probabilities are approximated with variational autoencoders.
label: none

sentence: During training the inference network is used, but during testing optimization based inference is carried out to compute loglikelihoods.
label: none

sentence: This paper focuses on the second part, with a different model.
label: none

sentence: Specifically, it proposes a specific Boltzmann machine to be used as a first layer of neural networks for MNIST classification.
label: none

sentence: This Boltzmann machine is pre-trained in two-stages using mean field inference of the binary latent variables and gradient estimation of the parameters.
label: none

sentence: This pre-trained model is then incorporated into the neural net for MNIST classification.
label: none

sentence: The existence of couplings J_h among the hidden units means that we have to carry out mean field inference over several iterations to compute the output activations of the model.
label: none

sentence: This is basically analogous to the optimization-based inference proposed by Schott et al. (As a detail, this optimization can be expressed as computation over several layers of a neural net.)
label: none

sentence: The authors compare to the work of Schott for one type of attack.
label: none

sentence: It would be nice to see more detailed experiments as done in Schott.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Questions:
label: none

sentence: 1- Why not use a single Boltzmann machine with 128 fully connected latent variables? Could you add this experiment please.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 2- Why is a two-stage pre-training (Figure 2) process needed? Why not just a single stage?
label: asp_replicability

sentence: 3- Is the key that you used only 679 patches containing 98% of occurrences in the dataset as the first stage? What if we vary this percentage? How sensitive are the results? Such experiments could be useful to understand better why your method appears to work well.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 4- Could you please add the found J_h's to the appendix.
label: arg_other

sentence: This architecture reminds me of the good old MRFs for image denoising.
label: none

sentence: Could it be that what we are seeing is the attack being denoised?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: I am puzzled and looking forward to answers to the above questions. I don't yet understand what is the thing that makes this approach appear to work, or why you were able to drop the Bayes inference inversion altogether as done by Schott.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Thanks in advance. I will re-adjust the review rating following your reply.
label: none

sentence: This paper proposes a new method to compare existing classifiers, which does not use fixed test set and adaptively sample it from an arbitrarily large corpus of unlabeled images.
label: none

sentence: The main idea seems similar to adopting active learning for the test set selection.
label: none

sentence: One of the main advantage is that it can select a sample set from an arbitrarily large unlabeled images.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: However, to compare different classifiers, the proposed algorithm still needs humans to annotate the selected dataset, which is very expensive compared with traditional methods.
label: none

sentence: Since this paper select the top-k images in D, if k is large the annotating for S will be very tedious, however if k is relatively small the method seems very sensitive to selected examples, which will make the comparison not totally convincing.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The authors invite five volunteer graduate students to annotate the selected example.
label: none

sentence: However, for many categories, it’s nor easy for normal people to distinguish.
label: none

sentence: So the experiments in this paper is also not convincing.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The paper addresses a challenging problem of predicting the states of entities over the description of a process.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: The paper is very well written, and easily understandable.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The authors propose a graph structure for entity states, which is updated at each step using the outputs of a machine comprehension system.
label: none

sentence: The approach is novel and well motivated.
label: asp_originality

sentence: I will suggest a few improvements:
label: none

sentence: 1. the NPN model seems a good alternative, will be good to have a discussion about why your model is better than NPN.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Also, NPN can probably be modified to output spans of a sentence.
label: none

sentence: I will be curious to know how it performs.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: 2. A more detailed illustration of the system / network is needed. Would have made it much easier to understand the paper.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 3. What are the results when using the whole training set of Recipes ?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The paper considers adaptive regularization, which has been popular in neural network learning.
label: none

sentence: Rather than adapting diagonal elements of the adaptivity matrix, the paper proposes to consider a low-rank approximation to the Gram/correlation matrix.
label: none

sentence: When you say that full-matrix computation "requires taking the inverse square root", I assume you know that is not really correct?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: As a matter of good implementation, one never takes the inverse of anything.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Instead, on solves a linear system, via other means.
label: none

sentence: Of course, approximate linear system solvers then permit a wide tradeoff space to speed things up.
label: none

sentence: There are several issues convolved here: one is ``full-matrix,'' another is that this is really a low-rank approximation to a matrix and so not full matrix, another is that this may or may not be implementable on GPUs.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The latter may be important in practice, but it is orthogonal to the full matrix theory.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: There is a great deal of discussion about full-matrix preconditioning, but there is no full matrix here.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Instead, it is a low-rank approximation to the full matrix.
label: none

sentence: If there were theory to be had here, then I would guess that the low-rank approximation may work even when full matrix did not, e.g., since the full matrix case would involve too may parameters.
label: none

sentence: The discussion of convergence to first order critical points is straightforward.
label: none

sentence: Adaptivity ratio is mentioned in the intro but not defined there.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Why mention it here, if it's not being defined.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: You say that second order methods are outside the scope, but you say that your method is particularly relevant for ill-conditioned problems.
label: none

sentence: It would help to clarify the connection between the Gram/correlation matrix of gradients and the Hessian and what is being done to ill-conditioning, since second order methods are basically designed for ill-conditioned problems..
label: asp_clarity

sentence: It is difficult to know what the theory says about the empirical results, given the tweaks discussed in Sec 2.2, and so it is difficult to know what is the benefit of the method versus the tweaks.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The results shown in Figure 4 are much more interesting than the usual training curves which are shown in the other figures.
label: asp_substance

sentence: If this method is to be useful, understanding how these spectral properties change during training for different types of networks is essential.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: More papers should present this, and those that do should do it more systematically.
label: none

sentence: You say that you "informally state the main theorem."  The level of formality/informality makes it hard to know what is really being said.  You should remove it if it is not worth stating precisely, or state it precisely.  (It's fair to modularize the proof, but as it is it's hard to know what it's saying, except that your method comes with some guarantee that isn't stated.)
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Evaluation on real world datasets are proposed to show the efficiency of the proposed method.

sentence: + The theory in this paper improve bounds for multi-source DA in previous paper.

sentence: The new bound provides new insight and helps the design of algorithm.
label: asp_originality

sentence: + This paper proposes elegant method to tackle new terms in the loss function and gives its complexity analysis.
label: asp_originality

sentence: + The evaluation results show that the algorithm is efficient.

sentence: Comments:
label: none

sentence: - The main contribution of the proposed theory is the alpha term.
label: none

sentence: Is \eta_{\mathcal{H}} is a better estimation that previous adaptability term in multi-source DA? What is the role of \eta_{\mathcal{H}} in the algorithm design? How to control it in empirical algorithm?

sentence: The authors consider the few-shot / meta-learning scenario in which the test set of interest is drawn from a different distribution from the training set.
label: none

sentence: This scenario
label: none

sentence: is well-motivated by the "researcher example" given throughout the paper.
label: none

sentence: The authors assume access to a large unlabelled set in test (target) domain, and a large labelled (few-shot) set in the source domain.
label: none

sentence: Thus, the paper is concerned with unsupervised version of the meta-learning problem under domain shift (i.e., a large amount of data unlabelled are available from the target domain).
label: none

sentence: The key idea is to learn a mapping from the source domain to the target domain.
label: none

sentence: This mapping is learned jointly with the meta-learner, who performs the meta-learning in the target domain, on examples from the labelled domain.
label: none

sentence: In practice however, it appears from the experimental section that the domain mapping is learned offline, and then frozen for the meta-learning phase.
label: none

sentence: Thus, at test time, given examples from the target domain, the meta-learner can perform few-shot learning.
label: none

sentence: Pros:
label: none

sentence: - The paper addresses an important scenario which has not been addressed to this point: namely, meta-learning without the assumption that the train and test sets are drawn from the same domain/distribution.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: - The authors propose a novel task and experimental framework for considering their method, and show (somewhat unsurprisingly) that their method outperforms standard meta-learning methods that do not properly account for domain shift.
label: asp_originality

sentence: - The paper reads well and is easy to follow.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Cons:
label: none

sentence: - My main concern is reproducibility: the authors employ a number of large architectures, complex loss functions, and regularizers / "additional improvements".
label: asp_replicability

sentence: Further, there a number of experimental details that need to be further elaborated upon.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: e.g., architectures and hyper-parameters used, and training procedures (I encourage the authors to utilize the appendices for this).
label: asp_replicability

sentence: It is unclear to me how difficult/easy these results would be to reproduce. Do the authors intend to release code for their implementations and experiments?
label: asp_replicability

sentence: - Some assumptions are not explicitly stated.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: In particular, it is unclear what the assumption on the size of the unlabelled test set is.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: This is also lacking from the description of the experimental protocol, which does not address the data-splits (how many classes were used for each) and size of the unlabelled test set.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - While the method is presented as jointly learning all the components, in the experimental section it is stated that the embedding network (the meta-learner) and the GAN-based domain adaptation are done separately. Can the authors comment on this further?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Is this different from first learning a image translation mapping (using the unlabelled data in the target domain), and then applying existing meta-learning models/algorithms to the labelled data in the target domain?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - The overall method seems to be not very principled, and requires a lot of "tweaks and tunes", with additional losses and regularizers, to work.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Overall, the paper proposes a method combining a number of existing useful works (prototypical networks for meta-learning and image-to-image translation for domain adaptation) to tackle an important problem setting that is not currently addressed in existing meta-learning research.
label: none

sentence: Further, it establishes a useful experimental benchmark for this task, and provides what appear to be reasonable results (though this is somewhat difficult to judge due to the lack of baseline approaches).
label: none

sentence: Hopefully, such a benchmark will inspire more researchers to explore this setting, and perhaps propose simpler, more principled approaches to perform this task.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: It is my impression that, if the authors elaborate on the experimental protocol and implementation details, this paper would be a good fit for the venue.
label: asp_substance

sentence: ## Summary ##
label: none

sentence: The authors apply policy gradients to combinatorial optimization problems.
label: none

sentence: They suggest a surrogate reward function that mitigates the variance in the reward, and hence the update size.
label: none

sentence: They demonstrate performance on a clique-finding problem.
label: none

sentence: ## Assessment ##
label: none

sentence: I don't think Cakewalk is different enough from the cross-entropy method to warrant acceptance in ICLR.
label: asp_originality

sentence: I also have concerns about the independence assumption in their sampling distribution (Section 3.2), and the fact that their experiments use the same set of (untuned) hyperparameters for each method.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: They both approximate the reward CDF from K samples and use this to construct a surrogate reward.
label: none

sentence: The difference is that Cakewalk uses the CDF directly, while CE uses a threshold function on the CDF.
label: none

sentence: ## Specific Comments and Questions ##
label: none

sentence: 1. Cakewalk is *very* closely related to the cross-entropy method.
label: none

sentence: The authors acknowledge this connection, but I think they should begin by introducing CE and then explain how Cakewalk generalizes it.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Both Cakewalk and CE approximate the reward CDF from K samples and use this to construct a surrogate reward.
label: none

sentence: The difference is that Cakewalk uses the CDF directly, while CE uses a threshold function on the CDF.
label: none

sentence: 2. The distribution proposed in section 3.2 assumes independence between the elements $x_j$. This seems problematic for some relatively simple problems.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Consider $x$ a binary vector and reward equal to the parity $S(x) = \sum{x_j} % 2$.
label: none

sentence: 3. In the experiments, there are large discrepancies between different optimizers on Cakewalk (e.g. SGA vs AdaGrad, Table 4).
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: Is there any explanation for this?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 4. How were the hyperparameters (learning rate, AdaGrad $\delta$, Adam $\beta_1, \beta_2$) chosen?
label: asp_replicability

sentence: It seems like a large assumption that the same learning rate would work for different methods, especially when some of them are normalizing the objective function.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: I would suggest tuning these values for each method independently.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: 5. It would be nice to see experimental results on more than one problem.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The authors discuss their results on k-medoids in the appendices, but it seems like these results aren't quite complete yet.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 6. In Table 3, the figure in bold is not the lowest (best) in the table.
label: none

sentence: The reason for this is only given in a single sentence at the end of Section 6, so it is a little confusing.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: I would replace these values with N/A or something similar.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: While the invertible model structure itself is essentially the same as Real-NVP, the use of observation variables in the framework with theoretically sound bidirectional training for safe use of the seemingly naïve inclusion of y (i.e., y and z can be independent).
label: none

sentence: Its abilities to model the posterior distributions of the inputs are supported by both quantitative and qualitative experiments.
label: none

sentence: The demonstration on practical examples is a plus.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The advantage of INN, however, is not crystal clear to me versus other generative methods such as GAN and VAE.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: This is an interesting paper overall, so I am looking forward for further discussions.
label: none

sentence: Pros:
label: none

sentence: 1.	Extensive analyses of the possibility of modeling posterior distributions with an INN have been shown.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Detailed experiment setups are provided in the appendix.
label: asp_substance

sentence: 2.	The theoretical guarantee (with some assumptions) of the true posterior might be beneficial in practice for relatively low-dimensional or less complex tasks.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Comments/Questions:
label: none

sentence: 1.	From the generative model point of view, could the authors elaborate on the comparison against cGAN (aside from the descriptions in Appendix 2)? It is quoted “cGAN…often lack satisfactory diversity in practice”.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Also, can cGAN be used estimate the density of X (posterior or not)?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: For the bidirectional training, did the ratios of the losses (L_z, L_y, L_x) have to be changed, or the iterations of forward/backward trainings have to be changed (e.g., 1 forward, 1 backward vs. 2 forward, 1 backward)?
label: none

sentence: This question comes from my observation that the nature of the losses, especially for L_y vs. L_y,L_x (i.e., SL vs. USL) seem to be different.
label: none

sentence: 3.	“we find it advantageous to pad both the in- and output of the network with equal number of zeros”: Is this to effectively increase the intermediate network dimensions?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Also, does this imply that for both forward and inverse process those zero-padded entries always come out to be zero?
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: It seems that there needs some way to enforce them to be zero to ensure that the propagation happens only among the entries belonging to the variables of interests (x, y and z).
label: none

sentence: 4.	It seems that most of the experiments are done in relatively small dimensional data.
label: none

sentence: This is not necessarily a drawback, I am curious if this model could succeed on higher dimensional data (e.g., image), especially with the observation y.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Overview:
label: none

sentence: This paper considers unsupervised (or self-supervised) discrete representation learning of speech using a combination of a recent vector quantized neural network discritization method and future time step prediction.
label: none

sentence: Discrete representations are fine-tuned by using these as input to a BERT model; the resulting representations are then used instead of conventional speech features as the input to speech recognition models.
label: none

sentence: New state-of-the-art results are achieved on two datasets.
label: none

sentence: Strengths:
label: none

sentence: The core strength of this paper is in the results that are achieved on standard speech recognition benchmarks.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: The results indicate that, while discritization in itself does not give improvements, coupling this with the BERT-objective results in speech features which are better in downstream speech recognition than standard features. I think the main technical novelty is in combining discritization with future time step prediction (but see the weakness below).
label: asp_originality

sentence: Weaknesses:
label: none

sentence: The main weakness of the paper is that it does not situate itself within existing literature in this area.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Over the last few years, researchers in the speech community have invested significant effort in learning better speech representations, and this is not discussed.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: See e.g. [1].
label: none

sentence: Even more importantly, very recently there has been a number of papers investigating discrete representations of speech; see the review [2].
label: none

sentence: Some of these papers specifically use VQ-VAEs [3].
label: none

sentence: [4] actually compares VQ-VAE and the Gumbel-Softmax approach.
label: none

sentence: These studies should be mentioned.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: This paper is different in that it incorporates future time step prediction.
label: none

sentence: But context prediction has also been considered before, also for speech [5, 6, 7].
label: none

sentence: This paper can be situated as a new contribution combining these two strands of research.
label: none

sentence: In the longer run it would be extremely beneficial to the community if this approach is applied to the standard benchmarks as set out in [2].
label: none

sentence: As a minor weakness, some parts of the paper is not described in enough detail and the motivation is weak or not exactly clear (see detailed comments below).
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Overall assessment:
label: none

sentence: I think the results as well as the new combination of existing approaches in the paper warrants publication. But it should be amended significantly to situate itself within the existing literature. I therefore award a "weak accept".
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Detailed questions and suggestions:
label: none

sentence: - Section 1: As motivation for this work, it is stated that "we aim to make well performing NLP algorithms more widely applicable".
label: none

sentence: As noted above, some NLP-like ideas (such as prediction of future speech segments, stemming from text-based language modelling) have already been considered within the speech community.
label: none

sentence: Rather than motivating the work in this way, it might be helpful to focus the contribution as a combination of future time step prediction and discretization (both of which have been considered in previous work, but not in combination).
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: - Section 4: Would it be possible to train the vq-wav2vec model jointly with BERT, i.e. as one model? I suspect it would be difficult since, for the masking objective, the discrete units are already required, but maybe there is a scheme where this could work.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: - Section 2.2: Similarly to the above question, would there be a way to incorporate the BERT principles directly into an end-to-end model, e.g. by randomly masking some of the continuous input speech?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: - Section 3.3: What exactly does "mode collapse" refer to in this context? Would this be using only one codebook entry, for instance?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: - Section 6: It seems that in all cases to obtain improvements from discritization, BERT is required on top of the vq-wav2vec discrete symbols.
label: none

sentence: Is it possible that the output acoustic model is simply better-matched to continuous rather than discrete input (direct vq-wav2vec gives discrete while BERT gives continuous)? Would it make sense to train the wav2vec acoustic model on top of the vqvae codebook entries (e) instead of directly on the symbols?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: This paper proposes an evaluation method for confidence thresholding defense models, as well as a new approach for generating of adversarial examples by choosing the wrong class with the most confidence when employing targeted attacks.
label: none

sentence: Although the idea behind this paper is fairly simple, the paper is very difficult to understand.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: I have no idea that what is the propose of defining a new evaluation method and how this new evaluation method helps in the further design of the MaxConfidence method.
label: asp_motivation-impact

sentence: Furthermore, the usage of the evaluation method unclear as well, it seems to be designed for evaluating the effectiveness of different adversarial attacks in Figure 2.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: However, in Figure 2, it is used for evaluating defense schemes.
label: none

sentence: Again, this confuses me on what is the main topic of this paper.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Indeed, why the commonly used attack success ratio or other similar measures cannot be used in the case?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Intuitively, it should provide similar results to the success-failure curve.
label: none

sentence: The paper also lacks experimental results, and the main conclusion from these results seems to be "MNIST is not suitable for benchmarking of adversarial attacks".
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: If the authors claim that the proposed MaxConfidence attack method is more powerful than the MaxLoss based attacks, they should provide more comparisons between these methods.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Meanwhile, the computational cost on large dataset such as ImageNet could be huge, the authors should further develop the method to make sure it works in all situations.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The paper studies the problem of question generation from sparql queries.
label: none

sentence: The motivation is to generate more training data for knowledge base question answering systems to be trained on.
label: none

sentence: However, this task is an instance of natural language generation: given a meaning representation (quite often a database record), generate the natural language text correspoding to it. And previous work on this topic has proposed very similar ideas to the scratchpad proposed here in order to keep track of what the neural decoder has already generated, here are two of them:
label: asp_originality

sentence: - Semantically Conditioned LSTM-based Natural Language Generation for Spoken Dialogue Systems
label: none

sentence: Tsung-Hsien Wen, Milica Gasic, Nikola Mrksic, Pei-Hao Su, David Vandyke, Steve Young, EMNLP 2015: https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.01745
label: none

sentence: - Globally Coherent Text Generation with Neural Checklist Models
label: none

sentence: Chloe Kiddon Luke Zettlemoyer Yejin Choi: https://aclweb.org/anthology/D16-1032
label: none

sentence: Thus the main novelty claim of the paper needs to be hedged appropriately.
label: asp_originality

sentence: Also, to demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method an appropriate comparison against previous work is needed.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: Some other points:
label: none

sentence: - How is the linearization of the inout done? It  typically matters
label: asp_substance

sentence: - Given the small size of the dataset, I would propose experimenting with non-neural approaches as well, which are also quite common in NLG.
label: asp_replicability

sentence: - On the human evaluation: showing the gold standard reference to the judges introduces bias to the evaluation which is inappropriate as in language generation tasks there are multiple correct answers.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: See this paper for discussion in the context of machine translation: http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P16-2013
label: none

sentence: - For the automatic evaluation measures there should be multiple references per SPARQL query since this is how BLEU et al are supposed to be used.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Also, this would allow to compare the references against each other (filling in the missing number in Table 4) and this would allow an evaluation of the evaluation itself: while perfect scores are unlikely, the human references should be much better than the systems.
label: asp_meaningful-comparison

sentence: - In the outputs shown in Table 3, the questions generated by the scratchpad encoder often seem to be too general compared to the gold standard, or incorrect.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: E.g. "what job did jefferson have" is semntically related to his role in the declaration of independence but rather different.
label: none

sentence: SImilarly, being married to someone is not the same as having a baby with someone.
label: none

sentence: While I could imagine human judges preferring them as they are fluent, I think they are wrong as they express a different meaning than the SPARQL query they are supposed to express.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: What were the guidelines used?
label: asp_clarity

sentence: The paper studies self-supervised learning from very few unlabeled images, down to the extreme case where only a single image is used for training.
label: none

sentence: From the few/single image(s) available for training, a data set of the same size as some unmodified reference data set (ImageNet, Cifar-10/100) is generated through heavy data augmentation (cropping, scaling, rotation, contrast changes, adding noise).
label: none

sentence: Three popular self-supervised learning algorithms are then trained on this data sets, namely (Bi)GAN, RotNet, and DeepCluster, and the linear probing accuracy on different blocks is compared to that obtained by training the same methods on the reference data sets.
label: none

sentence: The linear probing accuracy from the first few conv layers of the network trained on the single/few image data set is found to be comparable to or better than that of the same model trained on the full reference data set.
label: none

sentence: I enjoyed the paper; it addresses the interesting setting of an extremely small data set which complements the large number of studies on scaling up self-supervised learning algorithms.
label: asp_substance

sentence: I think it is not extremely surprising that using the proposed strategy allows to learn low level features as captured by the first few layers, but I think it is worth studying and quantifying.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The experiments are carefully described and presented, and the paper is well-written.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Here are a few questions and concerns:
label: none

sentence: - How much does the image matter for the single-image data set?
label: asp_substance

sentence: The selected images A and B are of very high entropy and show a lot of different objects (image A) and animals (image B). How do the results change if e.g. a landscape image or an abstract architecture photo is used?
label: asp_substance

sentence: - How general is the proposed approach? How likely is it to generalize to other approaches such as Jigsaw (Doersch et al., 2015) and Exemplar (Dosovitskiy et al., 2016)? It would be good to comment on this.
label: asp_substance

sentence: - [1] found that the network architecture for self-supervised learning can matter a lot, and that by using a ResNet architecture, performance of SSL methods can be significantly improved.
label: none

sentence: In particular, the linear probing accuracy appears to be often monotonic as a function of the depth of the layer it is computed from.
label: none

sentence: This is in contrast to what is observed for AlexNet in Tables 2 and 3, where the conv5 accuracy is lower than the conv4.
label: none

sentence: It would therefore be instructive to add experiments for ResNet to see how well the results generalize to other network architectures.
label: asp_substance

sentence: - Does the MonoGAN exhibit stable training dynamics comparable to training WGAN on CIFAR-10, or do the training dynamics change on the single-image data set?
label: asp_substance

sentence: Overall, I’m leaning towards accepting the paper, but it would be important to see how well the experiments generalize to i) ResNet and ii) other (lower entropy) input images.
label: asp_substance

sentence: [1] Kolesnikov, A., Zhai, X. and Beyer, L., 2019. Revisiting self-supervised visual representation learning.
label: none

sentence: arXiv preprint arXiv:1901.09005.
label: none

sentence: Update after rebuttal:
label: none

sentence: I thank the authors for their detailed response.
label: none

sentence: I appreciate the efforts of the authors into investigating the issues raised, the described experiments sound promising.
label: none

sentence: Unfortunately, the new results are not presented in the revision.
label: none

sentence: I will therefore keep my rating.

sentence: The authors propose a method for image restoration, where the restored image is the MAP estimate.
label: none

sentence: A pretrained GAN is utilized to approximate the prior distribution of the noise-free images.
label: none

sentence: Then, the likelihood induces a constraint which is based on the degradation function.
label: none

sentence: In particular, the method tries to find the latent point for which the GAN generates the image, which if gets degraded will match the given degraded image.
label: none

sentence: Also, an optimization algorithm is presented that solves the proposed constrained optimization problem.
label: asp_soundness-correctness

sentence: I find the paper very well written and easy to follow.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Also, the idea is pretty clean, and the derivations are simple and clear.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Additionally, the Figures 2,3 are very intuitive and nicely explain the theory.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: However, I think that there are some weaknesses (see comments):
label: none

sentence: Comments:
label: none

sentence: #1) I do not understand exactly what the "general method" means. Does it mean that you propose a method, where you can just change the F, such that to solve a different degradation problem? So you provide the general framework where somebody has to specify only the F?
label: asp_substance

sentence: #2) Clearly, the efficiency of the method is highly based on the ability of the GAN to approximate well the prior distribution of the noise-free images.
label: asp_substance

sentence: #3) There are several Equations that can be combined, such that to save enough white space in order to discuss further some actual technical details.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: For instance, Eq. 2,3 can be easily combined using the proportional symbol, Eq. 8,9,10,11 show actually the same thing.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: #4) I think that the function F has to be differentiable, and this should be mentioned in the text.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Also, I believe that some actual (analytic) examples of F should be provided, at least  in the experiments.
label: asp_substance

sentence: The same holds for the p(Omega).
label: asp_substance

sentence: This parameter Omega is estimated individually for each degraded image?
label: asp_substance

sentence: #5) Before Eq. 8 the matrix V is a function of z and should be presented as such in the equations.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: #6) I believe that it would be nice to include a magnified image of Fig. 3, where the gradient steps are shown.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Also, my understanding is that the optimization goal is to find first a feasible solution, and then find the point that maximizes f. I think that this can be clarified in the text.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: #7) The optimization steps seem to be intuitive, however, there is not any actual proof of converge.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Of course, the example in the Figure 3 is very nice and intuitive, but it is also rather simple.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: I would suggest, at least, to include some empirical evidences in the experiments that show convergence.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: #8) In the experiments I think that at least one example of F and p(Omega) should be presented.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Also, what the numbers in Table 4 show? Which is the best value that can be achieved?
label: asp_substance

sentence: These numbers correspond to several images, or to a unique image?
label: asp_substance

sentence: #9) I think that MNIST is almost a toy experiment, since the crucial component of the proposed method is the prior modeling with the GAN.
label: asp_substance

sentence: I believe that a more challenging experiment should be conducted e.g. using celebA dataset.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Minor comments:
label: none

sentence: #1) In the paragraph after Eq. 4 the equality p_r(x)=p_G(x) is very strong assumption.
label: asp_substance

sentence: I would suggest to use the \simeq symbol instead.
label: asp_substance

sentence: #2) After Eq. 6 the "nonnegative" should be "nonzero".
label: asp_substance

sentence: #3) Additional density estimation models can be used e.g. VAEs, GMM.

sentence: #4) In Section 2 paragraph 2, the sentence "However, they only ... and directly" is not clear what means.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: In general, I find both the proposed model and optimization algorithm interesting.
label: asp_substance

sentence: Additionally, the idea is nicely presented in the paper.
label: asp_clarity

sentence: Most of my comments are improvements which can be easily included.
label: arg_other

sentence: The two things that make me more skeptical, is the convergence of the proposed algorithm and the experiments.

sentence: The MNIST is a relatively simple experiment, and I would like to see how the method works in more challenging problems.
